declarationTitle: SEVERE STORMS, FLOODING, LANDSLIDES, AND MUDSLIDES
assistanceRequested: USGS Field measurements of flood-water heights in impacted communities in CT for 3612-EM-CT not to exceed 50 highwater marks.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) will provide advance support, real-time field measurements, and daily reporting of water heights in direct support and for situational awareness of FEMA disaster operations for a high-water or flood event.

USGS services may include, but are not limited to, the following in direct support of response and recovery operations:
 - Field measurements of flood water heights in impacted communities;
 - Deploy supplemental water-level measuring instruments.
 - Measure streamflow and discharge of flooded channels, directly or indirectly.
 - Flagging of High-Water Marks and collect evidence of flooding for impacted areas and communities. 
 - Locate and record the horizontal position and vertical elevation of the High Water Marks (HWM). 
 - Documentation of HWMs with field notes, digital photographs, and depth measurements to the ground at the HWM location at the time of inspection. 
 - Data measurements provided in GIS-ready format via the USGS National Water Information System or Short-Term Network system for display and download. 

Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.
3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency. 
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.

assistanceRequested: Request aerial imagery support for post landfall within FEMA Region 2 Area of Responsibility as pertains to Tropical Disturbance Invest 98L as applicable. Initial location is Puerto Rico and US Virgin Islands.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Air Force Auxiliary/Civil Air Patrol (CAP) will provide aircraft, vehicles, and/or personnel in support of FEMA disaster operations. Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
Aerial/ ground imaging (video, still photography, imagery, 2D/3Ddata) WALDO sorties as well as obliques and nadir Transportation of personnel and/or light cargo Damage assessment imagery/observations, which may include previously collected imagery Geotagged or georeferenced imagery, uploadable
to FEMA provided FTP website or delivered on digital media
CAP liaison and/or imagery collection management support Airborne communications relay (repeater) missions in support of FEMA Urban Search & Rescue/LifeSafety

Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
 - ESF-14 coordination and delivery of products and services
 - ESF-5 regarding critical physical and cyber infrastructure
- Analysis of impacts to Lifelines and National Critical Infrastructure 
CISA liaisons may include representatives from  
 - Integrated Operations Division (ESF14)
 - Infrastructure Security Division (Infrastructure SME) 
 - National Risk Management Center (Geospatial SME)

assistanceRequested:
Amendment #1: De-obligate funds and reissue as 3609EM-VT-COE-NAD-01
Activate USACE (ESF-3) to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will provide appropriate personnel to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities in support of disaster operations.  

Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
   - USACE support to RRCC 
   - USACE support to National and/or Regional IMAT 
   - USACE modeling and/or National Hurricane Program support
  -  USACE Local Government Liaison(s)
   - USACE support to ESF #15 External Affairs
   - USACE SME(s)
  -  Infrastructure Systems Recovery Support Function (IS-RSF) Field Coordinator (under NDRF)
  - Contract or OFA audit support to ensure costs incurred under USACE MAs meet all Stafford Act and regulatory requirements

This mission assignment may also fund other site-specific personnel and non-mission specific administrative and management support at a Recovery Field Office (RFO) or other USACE node locations.  Those costs are not considered in this initial estimate.  Costs would vary based on the magnitude and duration of the response and recovery operations as authorized by FEMA.

As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, DHS Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) will provide appropriate personnel to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other teams and facilities to support ESF-2 in disaster operations

Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.
3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency. 
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.

assistanceRequested: As directed by and in accordance with FEMA Region 2 Tropical Disturbance Operations Order 2024-15 and Activation/Deployment Memo for Record Email; FEMA Region 2 Emergency Support Function ESF 03 US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will deploy identified resources of the Time Phased Package of the Personnel Resource Deployment Plan to Region 2 RRCC, IOF/JFO in Commonwealth of Puerto Rico and/or Virgin Islands of the United States, and/or other identified facilities in support of FEMA disaster operations.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will provide appropriate personnel to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities in support of disaster operations.  
Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
   - USACE support to RRCC 
   - USACE support to National and/or Regional IMAT 
   - USACE modeling and/or National Hurricane Program support
  -  USACE Local Government Liaison(s)
   - USACE support to ESF #15 External Affairs
   - USACE SME(s)
  -  Infrastructure Systems Recovery Support Function (IS-RSF) Field Coordinator (under NDRF)
  - Contract or OFA audit support to ensure costs incurred under USACE MAs meet all Stafford Act and regulatory requirements
This mission assignment may also fund other site-specific personnel and non-mission specific administrative and management support at a Recovery Field Office (RFO) or other USACE node locations.  Those costs are not considered in this initial estimate.  Costs would vary based on the magnitude and duration of the response and recovery operations as authorized by FEMA.  
Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.
3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency. 
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.

assistanceRequested: Provide/stage high wheeled vehicles able to move cargo and/or passengers using DoD ground transportation assets in support of disaster operations. All local, State, and non-DoD national assets are exhausted or do not have the capacity to meet this requirement.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Dept of Defense (DOD) will provide/stage initial 30 high wheeled vehicles, adjusted as needed, able to move cargo and/or passengers, in support of disaster operations. DoD will provide requested support within capabilities and will determine most effective means of transportation based on available assets, delivery location, and required delivery timeline. Support will include required maintenance.

DOD is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission.

statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, General Services Administration (GSA) will provide appropriate personnel to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other teams and facilities as requested in support of disaster operations.
Activities may include, but are not limited to, the following:
- ESF-7 support
- Emergency leasing services for needed space/facilities as requested by FEMA
- GSA Lease Contracting Officers (LCOs) and others as needed
Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.
3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency. 
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.

statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Air Force Auxiliary/Civil Air Patrol (CAP) will provide aircraft, vehicles, and/or personnel in support of FEMA disaster operations.
Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- Aerial/ground imaging (video, still photography, imagery, 2D/3Ddata)

- Damage assessment imagery/observations, which may include previously collected
imagery
- Geo-tagged or georeferenced imagery, up-loadable to FEMA-provided FTP website or

statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, National Oceanic & Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) will provide support which may include, but is not limited to, rapidly collecting, processing, and distributing high resolution, geo-rectified aerial imagery and/or Light Detection and Ranging (LIDAR) data in support of disaster operations.
NOAA personnel will participate in Interagency Remote Sensing Coordination Cell (IRSCC) planning meetings, provide technical and operational planning expertise to facilitate aerial survey planning, and coordinate survey operations with other agencies (via the IRSCC, if activated).

statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will provide appropriate personnel to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities in support of disaster operations.  
Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
   - USACE support to RRCC 
   - USACE support to National and/or Regional IMAT 
   - USACE modeling and/or National Hurricane Program support
  -  USACE Local Government Liaison(s)
   - USACE support to ESF #15 External Affairs
   - USACE SME(s)
  -  Infrastructure Systems Recovery Support Function (IS-RSF) Field Coordinator (under NDRF)
  - Contract or OFA audit support to ensure costs incurred under USACE MAs meet all Stafford Act and regulatory requirements
This mission assignment may also fund other site-specific personnel and non-mission specific administrative and management support at a Recovery Field Office (RFO) or other USACE node locations. 2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.
3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency. 
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.

statementOfWork:
As requested by the state of North Carolina and directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Health and Human Services (HHS) will provide ESF 8 personnel, equipment transportation to stage to perform the functions of ESF 8 capabilities in support of disaster operations from the 2024 Debby incident. These functions include rapid health care
facility and healthcare system assessments in an impacted state(s), territorial or tribal jurisdiction(s). Requirements from FEMA 1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by
FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).

authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.

operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement
(ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.
9. A final inspection report will be completed upon termination of all direct Federal assistance work. Final inspection reports shall be signed by a representative of the performing Federal agency and the STT pursuant to 44 CFR.

statementOfWork:
At the direction of, and in coordination with FEMA security personnel, FPS will provide appropriate physical security to support response and recovery operations in the various
venues in Region 4. Security of FEMA facilities will be based on FEMA security standards, policies and practices. For FPS accounting purposes this MA and associated funds are
intended to fund FEMA task orders for the period specified or until funds are exhausted. Any time extensions or additional funding requirements will be processed utilizing an
RRF including new POP (period of performance) dates, cost estimate and justification. This information will be provided by FEMA Security in coordination with FPS personnel
and approved by the FCO or his/her designee. Equipment purchases are not authorized under this mission assignment.

assistanceRequested: USACE preposition two (2), adjusted as needed, Type Three (3) temporary emergency power resources to the affected area; staging in the vicinity of Greenville, SC
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will pre-position temporary power support assets for emergency power generation to the
affected area in support of disaster operations. 
Initial requirement is for two (2) Type Three (3) temporary power support assets, adjusted as needed
Assets provided by FEMA will be returned to the Distribution Center (DC)/Remote Storage Site (RSS) stock Fully Mission Capable (FMC). FEMA will supply or coordinate the
acquisition of generators and associated Bill of Materials (BOM) (e.g. wires, connectors and load banks). 
Work includes providing personnel and equipment at the Federal/State staging area. When directed by FEMA, USACE will conduct generator pre-installation operations. USACE
is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission including but not limited to Subject Matter Experts, members of the Planning and
Response Team (PRT), 249th Engineer Battalion, DTOS and ACI contractor.
Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory
authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.
3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA. 
5. The mission assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and
supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency. 
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still
operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement
(ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies

statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Air Force Auxiliary/Civil Air Patrol (CAP) will provide aircraft, vehicles, and/or personnel in support of FEMA disaster operations. Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
Aerial/ ground imaging (video, still photography, imagery, 2D/3Ddata) WALDO sorties as well as obliques and nadir Transportation of personnel and/or light cargo Damage assessment imagery/observations, which may include previously collected imagery Geotagged or georeferenced imagery, uploadable
to FEMA provided FTP website or delivered on digital media
CAP liaison and/or imagery collection management support Airborne communications relay (repeater) missions in support of FEMA Urban Search & Rescue/LifeSafety

Activate VHA OEM to NRCC ESF-8 PHMS
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA and HHS, Veterans Affairs (VA) - Veterans Health Administration (VHA) Office of Emergency Management (OEM) will provide appropriate personnel to the NRCC, other teams, and facilities to support disaster operations primarily as the FEMA-NRCC-PHMS (Public Health and Medical Specialist) and, at the request of the FEMA-NRCC-PHMUL (Public Health and Medical Unit Leader) the VHA may also serve as the acting PHMUL. If 24-hour coverage is necessary, VHA will support night shift requirements as staffing permits.
ADDITIONAL NOTES FROM FEMA:
- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), and durations of assignment(s)
- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. 
- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA. 
- The mission assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency. 
-MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

-------------------------------------------------
This is a reissuance of MA-23090401-COE-LRD-01:  Pre-position temporary emergency power resources to Region 1.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will pre-position temporary power support assets for emergency power generation to the affected area in support of disaster operations. 
Initial requirement is for two type IV temporary power support assets.
Assets provided by FEMA will be returned to the Distribution Center (DC)/Remote Storage Site (RSS) stock Fully Mission Capable (FMC).  FEMA will supply or coordinate the acquisition of generators and associated Bill of Materials (BOM) (e.g. wires, connectors and load banks).  
Work includes providing personnel and equipment at the Federal/State staging area.  When directed by FEMA, USACE will conduct generator pre-installation operations.  USACE is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission including but not limited to Subject Matter Experts, members of the Planning and Response Team (PRT), 249th Engineer Battalion, DTOS and ACI contractor.
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
--- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
--- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
--- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.
3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency. 
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.

assistanceRequested: Activate EPA to the NRCC or other facilities to support disaster operations
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) will provide appropriate personnel to the NRCC, or other facilities in support of disaster operations.
Activation may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- EPA support to NRCC
- EPA support to National IMAT
- EPA support to ESF #15 External Affairs
- EPA SME(s)
- Infrastructure Systems Recovery Support Function (IS-RSF) Field Coordinator (under NDRF)
- EPA modeling and/or National Hurricane Program support
- Contract or OFA audit support to ensure costs incurred under EPA MA meet all Stafford Act and regulatory requirements.
Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).

5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency. 
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. USAF Auxiliary, Civil Air Patrol (CAP) aerial support
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Air Force Auxiliary/Civil Air Patrol (CAP) will provide aircraft, vehicles, and/or personnel in support of FEMA disaster operations.
Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- Aerial/ground imaging (video, still photography, imagery, 2D/3Ddata)
- Transportation of personnel and/or light cargo
- Damage assessment imagery/observations, which may include previously collected
imagery
- Geo-tagged or georeferenced imagery, up-loadable to FEMA-provided FTP website or
delivered on digital media
- CAP liaison and/or imagery collection management support
- Airborne communications relay (repeater) missions in support of FEMA Urban Search & Rescue/Life-Safety

NOAA aircraft, survey crew, and remote sensing equipment to provide information regarding the nature and extent of Tropical Cyclone Debby and cascading effects
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, National Oceanic & Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) will provide support which may include, but is not limited to, rapidly collecting, processing, and distributing high resolution, geo-rectified aerial imagery and/or Light Detection and Ranging (LIDAR) data in support of disaster operations.
NOAA personnel will participate in Interagency Remote Sensing Coordination Cell (IRSCC) planning meetings, provide technical and operational planning expertise to facilitate aerial survey planning, and coordinate survey operations with other agencies (via the IRSCC, if activated).
NOAA is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission.
Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).

5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency. 
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.

assistanceRequested: FL Air Operations requests 2, adjusted as needed, rotary aircraft with hoist and rescue swimmer capability positioned on west side of storm, to immediately conduct SAR operations post storm
statementOfWork:
In support of the State of Florida's request, as directed by and in coordination with FEMA, U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) will provide assistance to Search and Rescue efforts when outside their statutory authority in accordance with the USCG FEMA Memo Policy Guidance on ESF # 9 Mission Assignments dated 16 August 2023 with the utilization of USCG assets to assist US&R Teams conducting Search and Rescue missions in support of Emergency Support Function (ESF) 9 for disaster operations.

For air missions, an approved task order via Air Operations Flight Request with AOBD/OSC signature is required for reimbursement.

While conducting a tasking, if USCG determines the work to be within USCG's statutory authority (e.g. phase changes), USCG will notify FEMA to ensure documentation that the tasking is no longer eligible for reimbursement under the MA.

USCG is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission.

Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.
3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.
9. A final inspection report will be completed upon termination of all direct Federal assistance work. Final inspection reports shall be signed by a representative of the performing Federal agency and the STT pursuant to 44 CFR.

Activate DOI Natural and Cultural Resources RSF personnel
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Dept of Interior (DOI) will provide appropriate personnel to the JFO, JRO, IOF or other teams and facilities in support disaster operations. 
Support may include, but is not limited to the following: 
- Natural and Cultural Resources Recovery Support Function support to the JFO and/or JRO. 
- Natural and Cultural Resources Recovery Support Function (NCR-RSF) Field Coordinator (under the National Disaster Recovery Framework). 
- NCR-RSF Recovery Support subject matter expertise. 
The Natural and Cultural Resources RSF Field Coordinator support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- Provide Subject Matter Expertise to the Federal Coordinating Officer (FCO) and Federal Disaster Recovery Officer (FDRO).
- Convene Federal partnering agencies supporting the NCR-RSF, formalize communications/meetings with the NCR-RSF, and serve as the federal point-person for all NCR-RSF-related matters at the field level.
- Maintain regular internal coordination/communication related to RSF initiatives at the field, regional, and national levels.
- Develop an approach to support natural and cultural resources recovery in alignment with goals and priorities set by state, tribe or territory with consideration of the local communities needs and/or regional situation.
- Provide technical assistance and collaborate with other agencies on recovery strategies/solutions, mitigation, resilience, and sustainability opportunities.
- Assist RSF agencies in continuing to incorporate a comprehensive, multi-sector approach on coordination activities.
- Develop and complete NDRF products that may include the Recovery Needs Assessment and/or performance tracking tools, as directed by the FDRO or FCO.
- Request additional support via Subject Matter Experts from pertinent Primary and Supporting agencies on an operation-by-operation basis.
- Monitor and support implementation of appropriate recovery programs.
- Provide support either deployed onsite, episodically, or virtually as determined by NCR RSF National Coordinator in collaboration with the FEMA FDRO.
ADDITIONAL INSTRUCTIONS: 
- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. 
- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA. - The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency. 
- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. 
-For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

declarationTitle: SEVERE STORMS, FLOODING, LANDSLIDES, AND MUDSLIDES
assistanceRequested:
Amendment #5: Request an extension for DOI through 30-August, 2024, no additional funding.
------------------------------------
Amendment #4: Request an extension of DOI-01 through 19 July, no addl. funding. ----- Activate DOI Natural and Cultural Resources RSF personnel
-------------------------------------
Amendment #3: Extend end date to 20 June 2024 with no additional funding.
Amendment #2:  Extend activation to 22 March 2024 and increase funding by $66,351.  
Amendment #1:  Extend activation to 22 December 2023 with no additional funding.
--------------------------------------------------------
Activate DOI Natural and Cultural Resources RSF personnel
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Dept of Interior (DOI) will provide appropriate personnel to the JFO, JRO, IOF or other teams and facilities in support disaster operations. 
Support may include, but is not limited to the following: 
- Natural and Cultural Resources Recovery Support Function support to the JFO and/or JRO. 
- Natural and Cultural Resources Recovery Support Function (NCR-RSF) Field Coordinator (under the National Disaster Recovery Framework). 
- NCR-RSF Recovery Support subject matter expertise. 
The Natural and Cultural Resources RSF Field Coordinator support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- Provide Subject Matter Expertise to the Federal Coordinating Officer (FCO) and Federal Disaster Recovery Officer (FDRO).
- Convene Federal partnering agencies supporting the NCR-RSF, formalize communications/meetings with the NCR-RSF, and serve as the federal point-person for all NCR-RSF-related matters at the field level.
- Maintain regular internal coordination/communication related to RSF initiatives at the field, regional, and national levels.
- Develop an approach to support natural and cultural resources recovery in alignment with goals and priorities set by state, tribe or territory with consideration of the local communities needs and/or regional situation.
- Provide technical assistance and collaborate with other agencies on recovery strategies/solutions, mitigation, resilience, and sustainability opportunities.
- Assist RSF agencies in continuing to incorporate a comprehensive, multi-sector approach on coordination activities.
- Develop and complete NDRF products that may include the Recovery Needs Assessment and/or performance tracking tools, as directed by the FDRO or FCO.
- Request additional support via Subject Matter Experts from pertinent Primary and Supporting agencies on an operation-by-operation basis.
- Monitor and support implementation of appropriate recovery programs.
- Provide support either deployed onsite, episodically, or virtually as determined by NCR RSF National Coordinator in collaboration with the FEMA FDRO.
ADDITIONAL INSTRUCTIONS: 
- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. 
- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA. - The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency. 
- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. 
-For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency. 
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.

USACE pre-position temporary emergency power resources to the affected area.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will pre-position temporary power support assets for emergency power generation to the affected area in support of disaster operations.
Initial requirement is for Type IV temporary power support assets with ability to expand or collapse as needed.
Assets provided by FEMA will be returned to the Distribution Center (DC)/Remote Storage Site (RSS) stock Fully Mission Capable (FMC). FEMA will supply or coordinate the acquisition of generators and associated Bill of Materials (BOM) (e.g. wires, connectors and load banks).
Work includes providing personnel and equipment at the Federal/State staging area. When directed by FEMA, USACE will conduct generator pre-installation operations. USACE is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission including but not limited to Subject Matter Experts, members of the Planning and Response Team (PRT), 249th Engineer Battalion, DTOS and ACI contractor.
Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.
3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.

statementOfWork:

- USACE modeling and/or National Hurricane Program support

- USACE support to ESF #15 External Affairs
- USACE SME(s)

assistanceRequested: CAP assistance in flying aerial imagery to support FEMA damage assessments. WALDO and Still Camera imagery
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Air Force Auxiliary/Civil Air Patrol (CAP) will provide aircraft, vehicles, equipment and/or personnel in support of FEMA disaster operations in Louisiana. 
Support may include, but is not limited to, the following: - Aerial/ground imaging (video, still photography, imagery, 2D/3Ddata) - Transportation of personnel and/or light cargo - Damage assessment imagery/observations, which may include previously collected imagery - Geo-tagged or georeferenced imagery, up-loadable to FEMA-provided FTP website or delivered on digital media - CAP liaison and/or imagery collection management support - Airborne communications relay (repeater) missions in support of FEMA Urban Search & Rescue/Life-Safety Requirements from FEMA: 1. This extension includes provisions for activating DOJ/ATF Law Enforcement Task Force for on-scene security, protection, and law enforcement.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the Department of Justice / Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives will provide a federal Law Enforcement Task Force or other security teams to manage, coordinate, equip, and sustain on-scene security, protection and law enforcement for federal operational support to response operations.
Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.
3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.

declarationTitle: SEVERE STORMS, FLOODING, LANDSLIDES, AND MUDSLIDES
assistanceRequested:
Amendment #4: Request an extension of DOI-01 through 19 July, no addl. funding. ----- Activate DOI Natural and Cultural Resources RSF personnel

-------------------------------------
Amendment #3: Extend end date to 20 June 2024 with no additional funding.
Amendment #2:  Extend activation to 22 March 2024 and increase funding by $66,351.  
Amendment #1:  Extend activation to 22 December 2023 with no additional funding.
--------------------------------------------------------
Activate DOI Natural and Cultural Resources RSF personnel
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Dept of Interior (DOI) will provide appropriate personnel to the JFO, JRO, IOF or other teams and facilities in support disaster operations. 
Support may include, but is not limited to the following: 
- Natural and Cultural Resources Recovery Support Function support to the JFO and/or JRO. 
- Natural and Cultural Resources Recovery Support Function (NCR-RSF) Field Coordinator (under the National Disaster Recovery Framework). 
- NCR-RSF Recovery Support subject matter expertise. 
The Natural and Cultural Resources RSF Field Coordinator support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- Provide Subject Matter Expertise to the Federal Coordinating Officer (FCO) and Federal Disaster Recovery Officer (FDRO).
- Convene Federal partnering agencies supporting the NCR-RSF, formalize communications/meetings with the NCR-RSF, and serve as the federal point-person for all NCR-RSF-related matters at the field level.
- Maintain regular internal coordination/communication related to RSF initiatives at the field, regional, and national levels.
- Develop an approach to support natural and cultural resources recovery in alignment with goals and priorities set by state, tribe or territory with consideration of the local communities needs and/or regional situation.
- Provide technical assistance and collaborate with other agencies on recovery strategies/solutions, mitigation, resilience, and sustainability opportunities.
- Assist RSF agencies in continuing to incorporate a comprehensive, multi-sector approach on coordination activities.
- Develop and complete NDRF products that may include the Recovery Needs Assessment and/or performance tracking tools, as directed by the FDRO or FCO.
- Request additional support via Subject Matter Experts from pertinent Primary and Supporting agencies on an operation-by-operation basis.
- Monitor and support implementation of appropriate recovery programs.
- Provide support either deployed onsite, episodically, or virtually as determined by NCR RSF National Coordinator in collaboration with the FEMA FDRO.
ADDITIONAL INSTRUCTIONS: 
- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. 
- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA. - The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency. 
- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. 
-For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

declarationTitle: SEVERE STORMS, FLOODING, LANDSLIDES, AND MUDSLIDES
assistanceRequested:
Amendment #1:  Extend activation to 22 December 2023 with no additional funding.
--------------------------------------------------------
Activate DOI Natural and Cultural Resources RSF personnel
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Dept of Interior (DOI) will provide appropriate personnel to the JFO, JRO, IOF or other teams and facilities in support disaster operations. 
Support may include, but is not limited to the following: 
- Natural and Cultural Resources Recovery Support Function support to the JFO and/or JRO. 
- Natural and Cultural Resources Recovery Support Function (NCR-RSF) Field Coordinator (under the National Disaster Recovery Framework). 
- NCR-RSF Recovery Support subject matter expertise. 
The Natural and Cultural Resources RSF Field Coordinator support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- Provide Subject Matter Expertise to the Federal Coordinating Officer (FCO) and Federal Disaster Recovery Officer (FDRO).
- Convene Federal partnering agencies supporting the NCR-RSF, formalize communications/meetings with the NCR-RSF, and serve as the federal point-person for all NCR-RSF-related matters at the field level.
- Maintain regular internal coordination/communication related to RSF initiatives at the field, regional, and national levels.
- Develop an approach to support natural and cultural resources recovery in alignment with goals and priorities set by state, tribe or territory with consideration of the local communities needs and/or regional situation.
- Provide technical assistance and collaborate with other agencies on recovery strategies/solutions, mitigation, resilience, and sustainability opportunities.
- Assist RSF agencies in continuing to incorporate a comprehensive, multi-sector approach on coordination activities.
- Develop and complete NDRF products that may include the Recovery Needs Assessment and/or performance tracking tools, as directed by the FDRO or FCO.
- Request additional support via Subject Matter Experts from pertinent Primary and Supporting agencies on an operation-by-operation basis.
- Monitor and support implementation of appropriate recovery programs.
- Provide support either deployed onsite, episodically, or virtually as determined by NCR RSF National Coordinator in collaboration with the FEMA FDRO.
ADDITIONAL INSTRUCTIONS: 
- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. 
- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA. - The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency. 
- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. 
-For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will provide appropriate personnel to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities in support of disaster operations.
Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- USACE support to RRCC
- USACE support to National and/or Regional IMAT
- USACE modeling and/or National Hurricane Program support
- USACE Local Government Liaison(s)
- USACE support to ESF #15 External Affairs
- USACE SME(s)
- Infrastructure Systems Recovery Support Function (IS-RSF) Field Coordinator (under NDRF)
- Contract or OFA audit support to ensure costs incurred under USACE MAs meet all Stafford Act and regulatory requirements

assistanceRequested: At the request of the State of Texas, execute Power Restoration Mission to support TDEM impacted counties from Hurrican Beryl.
statementOfWork:
n support of State of Texas request, as directed by and in coordination with FEMA, USACE will provide temporary power support assets to provide emergency power generation to the affected area in support of disaster operations.

Initial request is for USACE to activate and deploy one or more
Type II Temporary Emergency Power resources to EXECUTE a temporary emergency power mission with the ability to expand or contract to meet the need.

Assets provided by FEMA will be returned to the Distribution Center (DC)/Remote Storage Site (RSS) stocked Fully Mission Capable (FMC). FEMA will supply or coordinate the acquisition of generators and associated Bill of Materials (BOM) (e.g. wires, connectors and load banks). Work includes providing personnel and equipment at the Federal/State staging area and when directed by FEMA, USACE will conduct generator installation operations. USACE is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission including but not limited to Subject Matter Experts, members of the Planning and Response Team (PRT), 249th Engineer Battalion, DTOS and ACI contractor.

Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.
3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.
9. A final inspection report will be completed upon termination of all direct Federal assistance work. Final inspection reports shall be signed by a representative of the performing Federal agency and the STT pursuant to 44 CFR.

Amendment#1: POP start date corrected to 7.5.24 to align with verbal for TYPE II start date of 7.5.24.  Verbal attached.  No funding required.  Change PM to Dave Walker

This is a re-issue of TX-24070302-COE-LRD-01 for $1,500,000 with an additional $4,320,700.00 for total of $5,820,700.  This MA also replaces the verbal, for USACE pre-position temporary emergency power resources to the affected areas.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will pre-position temporary power support assets for emergency power generation to the affected area in support of disaster operations.
Initial requirement is for Type IV temporary power support assets with ability to expand or collapse as needed.
Assets provided by FEMA will be returned to the Distribution Center (DC)/Remote Storage Site (RSS) stock Fully Mission Capable (FMC). FEMA will supply or coordinate the acquisition of generators and associated Bill of Materials (BOM) (e.g. wires, connectors and load banks).
Work includes providing personnel and equipment at the Federal/State staging area. When directed by FEMA, USACE will conduct generator pre-installation operations. USACE is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission including but not limited to Subject Matter Experts, members of the Planning and Response Team (PRT), 249th Engineer Battalion, DTOS and ACI contractor.

1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).

3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.

assistanceRequested: Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) Aviation Division to provide aircraft to transport ESF #13 Personnel and LEST deployment packages. Pick up ESF 13 cache in Richmond, Virginia; fly to Puerto Rico San Juan airport DEA hanger to refuel and pick up 4 pax, then fly ESF 13 cache to USVI St. Croix and then fly to St. Thomas Cyril E. King Airport; then fly back to Ft. Lauderdale
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the Department of Justice/ESF 13 will coordinate movement of appropriate personnel supporting ESF #13 as requested in support of FEMA disaster operations. Support may include, but not limited to, tasking the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) Aviation Division to provide aircraft to transport ESF #13, ESF #9, and ESF #8 and/or their respective equipment to Puerto Rico/USVI in support of lifesaving operations. Aircraft will remain on standby to provide continued aviation support to ESFs 13/9/8 (inter-island transportation etc.) and other FEMA missions as needed and coordinated.

--MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, additional personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).

Amend 1 - Correction to Section III Action To  ESF 14
As directed by and in accordance with FEMA Region 2 Tropical Disturbance Operations Order 2024-12 and Activation/Deployment Memo for Record Email; FEMA Region 2 Emergency Support Function ESF 14 DHS Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) will deploy identified resources of the Time Phased Package of the Personnel Resource Deployment Plan to Region 2 RRCC, IOF/JFO in Commonwealth of Puerto Rico and/or Virgin Islands of the United States, and/or other identified facilities in support of FEMA disaster operations.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA,  DHS Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) will provide appropriate personnel to the RRCC, JFO, IOF, or other teams and facilities in support of disaster operations.

Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
 - ESF-14 coordination and delivery of products and services
 - ESF-5 regarding critical physical and cyber infrastructure
- Analysis of impacts to Lifelines and National Critical Infrastructure 

CISA liaisons may include representatives from  
 - Integrated Operations Division (ESF14)
 - Infrastructure Security Division (Infrastructure SME) 
 - National Risk Management Center (Geospatial SME)

Amendment 1: de-ob ($1.7M FY24) per attached email.
As directed by and in accordance with FEMA Region 2 Tropical Disturbance Operations Order 2024-12 and Activation/Deployment Memo for Record Email; FEMA Region 2 Emergency Support Function ESF 03 US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) Temporary Power Teams will deploy identified resources of the Time Phased Package of the Personnel Resource Deployment Plan to Region 2 RRCC, IOF/JFO in Commonwealth of Puerto Rico and/or Virgin Islands of the United States, and/or other identified facilities in support of FEMA disaster operations.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will pre-position temporary power support assets for emergency power generation to the affected area in support of disaster operations. 

Initial requirement is for up to but not limited to:
Temporary Power Subject Matter Expert
Temporary Power PRT ADVON
ACI Temporary Power ADVON
249th Engineering Battalion ADVON
Temporary Power PRT Type IV
249th Engineering Battalion Type IV
Type IV Power ACI

Assets provided by FEMA will be returned to the Distribution Center (DC)/Remote Storage Site (RSS) stock Fully Mission Capable (FMC).  FEMA will supply or coordinate the acquisition of generators and associated Bill of Materials (BOM) (e.g. wires, connectors and load banks).  

Work includes providing personnel and equipment at the Federal/State staging area.  When directed by FEMA, USACE will conduct generator pre-installation operations.  USACE is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission including but not limited to Subject Matter Experts, members of the Planning and Response Team (PRT), 249th Engineer Battalion, DTOS and ACI contractor.

1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).

incidentName: R5 Minnesota June 2024 Flooding and Severe Weather
assistanceRequested: In coordination with FEMA, the Dept of Defense (DOD) will provide and support an Initial Operating Facility (IOF).
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Department of Defense (DoD) Office will provide and support a facility space to function as a FEMA Initial Operating Facility in
support of FEMA disaster operations. Initial installation requirements may include but are not limited to the following: office space or workstations for 30-50 Federal and/or state personnel. This includes standard utilities (electricity, heat, air conditioning, light, ventilation, sanitation, trash removal, and cleaning services).

FEMA will provide its own local area wireless network; phone and internet services is not required. FEMA requires 7 days a week access to the space. The workspace should be securable (locking doors) and have access to parking for at least 30 passenger vehicles. FEMA personnel may have to relocate to another area if the current space needs to be reallocated. No billeting, medical support, or staff augmentation is required.

MATOs may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment (s).

Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.

The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

agency

statementOfWork:

imagery

Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- Aerial/ground imaging (video, still photography, imagery, 2D/3Ddata)
- Transportation of personnel and/or light cargo
- Damage assessment imagery/observations, which may include previously collected
imagery
- Geo-tagged or georeferenced imagery, up-loadable to FEMA-provided FTP website or
delivered on digital media
- CAP liaison and/or imagery collection management support
- Airborne communications relay (repeater) missions in support of FEMA Urban Search & Rescue/Life-Safety

Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.
3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.

declarationTitle: SEVERE STORMS, FLOODING, STRAIGHT-LINE WINDS, AND TORNADOES
assistanceRequested:
Amendment#1 Extend Period of Performance (PoP) to 11/01/2024; no additional funds needed.
Activate Health and Human Services (HHS) Administration for Strategic Preparedness and Response (ASPR) to provide appropriate Health & Social Services Recovery Support Function (HSS-RSF) personnel in support of the National Disaster Recovery Framework (NDRF) and FEMA post-disaster recovery operations for DR-4796/4784-IA (Iowa Severe Storms).
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, HHS/ASPR will provide an HSS RSF Field Coordinator (FC) to the IOF, JFO, or other, including virtual, to coordinate the HSS RSF in support of FEMA and NDRF integrated operations to achieve recovery outcomes.
The HSS RSF Field Coordinator will provide federal coordination with the appropriate RSF primary and support agencies, other Federal Agencies, and STTL partners as directed by FEMA.
The HHS RSF Field Coordinator will provide specific expertise to the RSFs, the Deputy Federal Coordinating Officer for Recovery, and Federal Disaster Recovery Officer (FDRO) as needed to conduct a Recovery Needs Assessment (RNA) process.
Through collaboration, the HSS RSF FC will contribute to development of the HSS RSF RNA, and will:
- Identify significant cross-sector HSS RSF recovery issues in impacted areas, and additional resources to support long-term recovery, with special focus on supporting unmet recovery needs in the Health & Social Services core mission areas of education and behavioral health.
- In conjunction with other federal agencies and STTL partners, identify recovery outcomes and strategies for identified HSS RSF recovery issues where Iowa officials request recovery support.
- Serve as the Federal point-person for ASPR Recovery personnel and SMEs from other federal agencies to ensure SMEs in healthcare, behavioral health, public/environmental health, social services, and education are all represented.
- Participate in Recovery Coordination Group meetings and strategic work sessions and collaborate with STTL partners to identify recovery considerations and develop recovery outcomes and strategies that can be supported with Federal resources and services.
The HSS RSF Field Coordinator in consultation with the HSS RSF National Coordinator, may request additional Subject Matter Expert support from pertinent primary and supporting agencies, on an operation-by-operation basis.
Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.
3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.
