declarationTitle: SEVERE STORMS, FLOODING, STRAIGHT-LINE WINDS, AND TORNADOES
assistanceRequested:
Amendment #1 Change Project Manager to Rachel Fails; no additional funds needed.
EPA oil and hazardous materials field operations for disaster operations in the State of Iowa
statementOfWork:
In support of Iowa request, as directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) will conduct oil and hazardous materials field operations, including assessment, mitigation, cleanup and disposal of hazardous materials and oil and response to orphaned containers and/or fixed facilities in support of FEMA disaster operations. These necessary emergency protective measures will mitigate actual and potential threats to public health and safety.
In close coordination with FEMA, EPA response operations may also include the following:
- household hazardous waste identification, collection, and disposal
- evaluating and monitoring immediate public health and safety threats or hazards resulting from debris removal operations The assistance may include response to eliminate or lessen immediate threats to lives, public health, or safety emanating from actual or potential releases and/or discharges;
- Support of field personnel by EPA personnel deployed virtually;
- providing specialized expertise related to oil/hazmat impacts or release;
- conducting damage assessment of oil/hazmat impact via air, soil, and/or water;
- contractor oversight; and/or
- response, removal, mitigation, staging or disposal oversight of actual and potential oil discharges and releases of hazardous materials.
EPA will coordinate activities involving contaminated debris with USACE as appropriate. Actions may include support by any special teams requested by the Federal On-Scene Coordinator (FOSC) and in coordination with FEMA, as well as special technical assets of all ESF #10 support agencies.
EPA is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission.
Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.
3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.
9. A final inspection report will be completed upon termination of all direct Federal assistance work. Final inspection reports shall be signed by a representative of the performing Federal agency and the STT pursuant to 44 CFR.

1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.
3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.

assistanceRequested: USACE provide emergency planning of potential sites for housing in support of FEMA direct housing operations.

declarationTitle: SEVERE STORMS, FLOODING, STRAIGHT-LINE WINDS, AND TORNADOES
assistanceRequested:
Amendment#1  Amend to extend period of performance to 9-30-24 no additional funds needed; change PM to Naomi Bullock.
Deploy CNCS field personnel to support disaster operations
statementOfWork:
In support of the State of Iowa request, as directed by and in accordance with duties outlined in the FEMA/AmeriCorps MOU AmeriCorps personnel as directed by FEMA, Corporation for National Community Service (CNCS) will deploy personnel to support activities including, but not limited to, the following areas in support of FEMA disaster operations: mucking/gutting shelter, feeding, donations and volunteer management, warehousing, non-hazardous disaster debris removal, tarping under the approved USACE program, chain-saw work (for qualified crews only), call centers, volunteer base camp, needs assessment, and long-term recovery committees.
CNCS will provide support in accordance with duties outlined in the FEMA/CNCS MOU and as directed by the FEMA ESF #6 assigned Regional Lead or designee.
Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.
3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.
9. A final inspection report will be completed upon termination of all direct Federal assistance work. Final inspection reports shall be signed by a representative of the performing Federal agency and the STT pursuant to 44 CFR.

- Integrated Operations Division (ESF14)
- Infrastructure Security Division (Infrastructure SME)
- National Risk Management Center (Geospatial SME)
Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.
3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.

- USACE support to RRCC
- USACE support to National and/or Regional IMAT
- USACE modeling and/or National Hurricane Program support

assistanceRequested: USFS command and control support for all hazard operations including flood response for the State of New Mexico
statementOfWork:
In support of the request of the State of New Mexico, as directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Forest Service (USFS) will provide command, control, and coordination resources, including but not limited to command and general staff members or personnel with other specialized qualifications, to assist with all hazard emergency operations to support FEMA disaster operations for DR4795.
- USFS will utilize other Federal agency and State/local resources under existing agreement, as appropriate.  
- USFS will pre-position resources and/or provide assistance.  
- USFS is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission.

NGA Geospatial Intelligence (GEOINT) support for FEMA Urban Search and Rescue (US&R) deployed supporting the New Mexico Wildfires response.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency (NGA) will deploy Geospatial Analyst Team(s) to assist the Urban Search & Rescue (US&R) Incident Support Team and deployed task forces in support of disaster operations.
Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- Mobile GEOINT Support Team (MGST): Heavy, Medium, or Light 
- NGA analysts to provide analytical expertise
- NGA operational support staff including contractors to support operations, satellite communications, and sheltering and feeding of NGA staff (a total of 12 personnel to provide mobile GEOINT)
NGA is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission.
Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).

6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.

assistanceRequested:

HHS behavioral health care services in support of disaster operations.
statementOfWork:
In support of the State of New Mexico's request, as directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Health & Human Services (HHS) will assist State and local staff in providing mental health and substance abuse support services to disaster victims, their families, and rescue response workers.
Support by HHS mental health teams services may include but is not limited to the following:
- Conduct screening and assessment of community needs relevant to mental and behavioral conditions (e.g., acute/chronic stress reactions and substance abuse)
- Provide grief counseling and psychological first aid to incident victims and responders.
- Development and operation of targeted workshops and trainings (see examples **)
- Support for mental health and/or shelter needs assessments
- HHS ASPR TRACIE and emPOWER resources
- Consultation and expertise regarding provision of psychological first aid and crisis counseling support to incident survivors and/or responders
- Health and Social Services Recovery Support Function (HSS
RSF) Field Coordinator (under NDRF)
- HSS Recovery Support Subject Matter Experts (SME)(s)
- Contract or OFA audit support to ensure costs incurred under HHS Mission Assignments (MAs) meet all Stafford Act and regulatory requirements
FEMA logistical support: Teams may require some level of base operating support (food, shelter, laundry, etc.).
Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.
3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.
9. A final inspection report will be completed upon termination of all direct Federal assistance work. Final inspection reports shall be signed by a representative of the performing Federal agency and the STT pursuant to 44 CFR.

Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).

declarationTitle: SOUTH FORK FIRE, SALT FIRE, AND FLOODING
assistanceRequested:
Amendment 1: Extend POP date to 30 July 2024
Requesting Water/Wastewater SME to support USACE IA Mission.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) will deploy personnel to provide event-specific planning, preparation, and execution, only at the request of FEMA, for the drinking water and wastewater infrastructure/safety mission in coordination with Emergency Support Function (ESF) 3 for disaster operations.
Activities may include, but are not limited to: sampling and analysis, facility assessments, liaison among Federal, State, local, Tribal, and municipal representatives concerning planning and execution efforts, generating lists of public water systems (PWSs) and publicly owned treatment works (POTWs) within areas affected by the incident, preliminary facility surveys (e.g. operational status, emergency power status/need, physical damage), laboratory support for water sample collection, coordination of essential resources (fuel, treatment chemicals, and personnel), reach back support, and appropriate personnel to manage the EPA field operations.
Requirements from FEMA: 1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement. 3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA. 5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency. 6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided. 7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact. 8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.

declarationTitle: SOUTH FORK FIRE, SALT FIRE, AND FLOODING
assistanceRequested:
Amendment #2: Align POP with Operational Period. MA was operationally closed 06/29/24. And change PM to Tom Erickson.
Amend #1: Extend POP to 4 July 2024 and increase funds by $90,300.
Requesting USACE provide Infrastructure Assessment PRT to IOF for planning, preparedness, and federally requested assessments.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will preposition elements of the Infrastructure Assessment (IA) Planning & Response Team (PRT) management cell to conduct initial planning, preparedness, and field assessments in support of federal disaster operations.
Support may include the following:
Determining the need for supporting local public works with rapid evaluation safety assessments, heavy structural inspections (e.g., to help ensure viability of structures that may be used for mass care, emergency housing, etc.), and Nonstructural assessments (e.g. electrical, mechanical, geotechnical, water/wastewater infrastructure, etc.), and evaluating/assessing damaged public facilities, hospitals, and other structures. USACE is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission.
Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory
authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.

5. The mission assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 1040103.
For MAs still
operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

declarationTitle: SOUTH FORK FIRE, SALT FIRE, AND FLOODING
assistanceRequested:
Amendment #2: Amend to align POP with operational period. MA was operationally closed 06/29/24. And change PM to Tom Erickson.
Amend #1: Amend to increase funding by $1,567,650.00 and extend POP end date to 4 July 2024.
USACE pre-position temporary emergency power resources to the affected area.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will pre-position temporary emergency power assets associated with a Type III package to aid in accomplishing priority missions in support of disaster operations
Assets provided by FEMA will be returned to the Distribution Center (DC)/Remote Storage Site (RSS) stock Fully Mission Capable (FMC).  FEMA will supply or coordinate the acquisition of generators and associated Bill of Materials (BOM) (e.g. wires, connectors and load banks).  
Work includes providing personnel and equipment at the Federal/State staging area.  When directed by FEMA, USACE will conduct generator pre-installation operations.  USACE is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission including but not limited to Subject Matter Experts, members of the Planning and Response Team (PRT), 249th Engineer Battalion, DTOS and ACI contractor.
Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.

Activate USACE to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will provide appropriate personnel to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities in support of disaster operations.  
Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
   - USACE support to RRCC 
   - USACE support to National and/or Regional IMAT 
   - USACE modeling and/or National Hurricane Program support
  -  USACE Local Government Liaison(s)
   - USACE support to ESF #15 External Affairs
   - USACE SME(s)
  -  Infrastructure Systems Recovery Support Function (IS-RSF) Field Coordinator (under NDRF)
  - Contract or OFA audit support to ensure costs incurred under USACE MAs meet all Stafford Act and regulatory requirements
This mission assignment may also fund other site-specific personnel and non-mission specific administrative and management support at a Recovery Field Office (RFO) or other USACE node locations.  Those costs are not considered in this initial estimate.  Costs would vary based on the magnitude and duration of the response and recovery operations as authorized by FEMA.

SAF Auxiliary, Civil Air Patrol (CAP) aerial imaging in support of Region 7 Severe Storms in IOWA, 
22 MAY 2024
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Air Force Auxiliary/Civil Air Patrol (CAP) will provide aircraft, vehicles, and/or personnel in support of FEMA disaster operations.
Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- Aerial/ground imaging (video, still photography, imagery, 2D/3Ddata)
- Transportation of personnel and/or light cargo
- Damage assessment imagery/observations, which may include previously collected
imagery
- Geo-tagged or georeferenced imagery, up-loadable to FEMA-provided FTP website or
delivered on digital media
- CAP liaison and/or imagery collection management support
- Airborne communications relay (repeater) missions in support of FEMA Urban Search & Rescue/Life-Safety

USFS command and control support for all-hazards response and recovery operations
statementOfWork:
In support of State of Iowa request, as directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Forest Service (USFS) will provide command, control, and coordination resources, to include All-Hazards Incident Management command and general staff members or personnel with other specialized qualifications, to assist with emergency operations in support of response and recovery operations.
USFS will utilize other Federal agency and State/local resources under existing agreement, as appropriate.
Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.
3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.
9. A final inspection report will be completed upon termination of all direct Federal assistance work. Final inspection reports shall be signed by a representative of the performing Federal agency and the STT pursuant to 44 CFR.

assistanceRequested: This is a re-issuance of MA#1509-467569-7220SU-IA-24052102-DoD-USAF-01-$15,000.00
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Air Force Auxiliary/Civil Air Patrol (CAP) will provide aircraft, vehicles, and/or personnel in support of FEMA disaster operations.

Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- Aerial/ground imaging (video, still photography, imagery, 2D/3Ddata)
- Transportation of personnel and/or light cargo
- Damage assessment imagery/observations, which may include previously collected
imagery
- Geo-tagged or georeferenced imagery, up-loadable to FEMA-provided FTP website or
delivered on digital media
- CAP liaison and/or imagery collection management support
- Airborne communications relay (repeater) missions in support of FEMA Urban Search & Rescue/Life-Safety

Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.
3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.

assistanceRequested: USACE specialized expertise for oversight of debris operations in support of disaster operations. Initial request is for 2 personnel
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, USACE will provide specialized expertise for oversight of debris operations
in support of disaster operations. Support may include the following: providing information on technical requirements
for debris operations, increasing the efficiency of such operations, efficient monitoring techniques, documentation
requirements, etc. USACE is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission.
Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory
authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.
3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
5. The missionassigned
agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and
supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 1040103.
For MAs still
operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement
(ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.

statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Federal Protective Service (FPS) will provide appropriate physical security of FEMA facilities based on FEMA security standards, policies, and practices.
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
--- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
--- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
--- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

assistanceRequested:
Amend #1: Amend to fully de-obligate and transfer to 4776DR-OK-DOD-USAF- 01 MA.
USAF Auxiliary, Civil Air Patrol (CAP) aerial support
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Air Force Auxiliary/Civil Air Patrol (CAP) will provide aircraft, vehicles, and/or personnel in support of FEMA disaster operations.
Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- Aerial/ground imaging (video, still photography, imagery, 2D/3Ddata)
- Transportation of personnel and/or light cargo
- Damage assessment imagery/observations, which may include previously collected
imagery
- Geo-tagged or georeferenced imagery, up-loadable to FEMA-provided FTP website or
delivered on digital media
- CAP liaison and/or imagery collection management support
- Airborne communications relay (repeater) missions in support of FEMA Urban Search & Rescue/Life-Safety

incidentName: R6 Severe Storms OK, TX, AR, LA
declarationTitle: SEVERE STORMS, STRAIGHT-LINE WINDS, TORNADOES, AND FLOODING
assistanceRequested: Request HUD specialized expertise to FEMA to support the State-Led Housing Task Force (HTF)
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Housing & Urban Development (HUD) will deploy personnel to provide specialized expertise to FEMA to support the State-Led Housing Task Force (HTF) in support of FEMA disaster operations. Activities may include, but are not limited to, identification of available housing stock, review of existing Federal and State programs and authorities, assistance with the development of disaster specific housing plans, and providing housing community and economic redevelopment expertise to promote recovery efforts. HUD personnel may be tasked to support the housing resource databases. HUD is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission. 
Requirements from FEMA: 1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement. 3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA. 5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency. 6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided. 7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact. 8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.

This MA replaces the verbal activation work and cost.  
Activate USACE to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities to include virtual.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will provide appropriate personnel to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities in support of disaster operations.

Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- USACE support to RRCC
- USACE support to National and/or Regional IMAT
- USACE modeling and/or National Hurricane Program support
- USACE Local Government Liaison(s)
- USACE support to ESF #15 External Affairs
- USACE SME(s)
- Infrastructure Systems Recovery Support Function (IS-RSF) Field Coordinator (under NDRF)
- Contract or OFA audit support to ensure costs incurred under USACE MAs meet all Stafford Act and regulatory requirements

This mission assignment may also fund other site-specific personnel and non-mission specific administrative and management support at a Recovery Field Office (RFO) or other USACE node locations. Those costs are not considered in this initial estimate. Costs would vary based on the magnitude and duration of the response and recovery operations as authorized by FEMA.

Requirements from FEMA:
1. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
2. Agencies may be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement.
3. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
4. Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
5. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.
6. MAs shall be considered for fiscal closure or reduction of obligations 180 days after the projected end date in accordance with the FEMA Policy 104-010-3. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
7. Prior to departing disaster operations, provide FEMA with details on status of any ongoing actions, property disposition (if applicable), and Financial/Program points of contact.
8. Sharing of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) between the agencies is not authorized by this MA. The agencies must complete an Information Sharing Access Agreement (ISAA), an Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) and/or a Privacy Threshold Analysis (PTA), if required by either Agency, before data is transferred between the agencies.

statementOfWork:

- ESF-7 support
- Emergency leasing services for needed space/facilities as requested by FEMA
- GSA Lease Contracting Officers (LCOs) and others as needed
-MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).

-Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
-The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency
-MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

DOD provide and support facility(s) as a FEMA Incident Support Base (ISB), Federal Staging Area (FSA), and/or FEMA Federal Team Staging Facility (FTSF)
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Dept of Defense (DOD) will provide and support a facility to function as a FEMA Incident Support Base (ISB), a Federal Staging Area (FSA) to support forward distribution of supplies or equipment, and/or a FEMA Federal Team Staging Facility (FTSF) for personnel and teams to the affected area(s) or other locations as required in support of FEMA disaster operations.
DOD will provide, MCAS Miramar and support as an ISB, FSA, and/or FTSF.
Initial installation requirements may include, but are not limited to, the following:
Secure Marshaling Area for Approximately 5 trucks and Estimated 2 trailers.
DOD is responsible for providing equipment personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission.
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
The mission assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and
supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency
MA will be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

DOD provide and support March ARB as a FEMA Incident Support Base (ISB), Federal Staging Area (FSA), and/or FEMA Federal Team Staging Facility (FTSF)
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Dept of Defense (DOD) will provide and support March ARB to function as a FEMA Incident Support Base (ISB), a Federal Staging Area (FSA) to support forward distribution of supplies or equipment, and/or a FEMA Federal Team Staging Facility (FTSF) for personnel and teams to the affected area(s) or other locations as required in support of FEMA disaster operations.    
Initial installation requirements may include, but are not limited to, the following:
Marshalling area: 20 trucks/trailers, 3-5 acres hardstand
Sufficient MHE vehicles/aircraft trans load
Office space/desks for 15 personnel. No life support. EPLO on site
DOD is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission.
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
The mission assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.
MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

Activate ESF 3 USACE to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will provide appropriate personnel to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities in support of disaster operations.
Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- USACE support to RRCC
- USACE support to National and/or Regional IMAT
- USACE modeling and/or National Hurricane Program support
- USACE Local Government Liaison(s)
- USACE support to ESF #15 External Affairs
- USACE SME(s)
- Infrastructure Systems Recovery Support Function (IS-RSF) Field Coordinator (under NDRF)
- Contract or OFA audit support to ensure costs incurred under USACE MAs meet all Stafford Act and regulatory requirements
This mission assignment may also fund other site-specific personnel and non-mission specific administrative and management support at a Recovery Field Office (RFO) or other USACE node locations. Those costs are not considered in this initial estimate. Costs would vary based on the magnitude and duration of the response and recovery operations as authorized by FEMA.

- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.

- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

assistanceRequested:
Requesting GSA assistance with sourcing and leasing a commercial office space in Warwick RI.  Facility requirements 19,000 - 22,000sq. Ft. commercial office space.
Additional requirements: ADA compliant, 150 - 200 parking spots, loading dock, wrap around services to be included.
Activation - GSA start date 03/27/2024 for 30 days.
Requested Resources: Activation - GSA
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, General Services Administration (GSA) will provide personnel to assist in leasing realty and/or contracting support and/or purchases as required to support FEMA disaster operation for DR-4766. Initial request is for GSA to find and assist in the leasing of a suitable location in Warwick, RI area. Details will be provided in a Mission Assignment Task Order as necessary.
--Funding of leases, contracts, or purchases in not authorized under this Mission Assignment. Leases, contracts, or purchases will be funded separately.
--MA task orders (MATOS) may be issues by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignments(s).
--Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CRF. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
--All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
--The mission assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency. 
--MAs shall be considered for closure after 45 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MA's still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

Provide USDA disaster program subject matter expertise to FCO and also at disaster field offices, specifically in mostly rural counties, in support of Individual Assistance Staff.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) will provide appropriate personnel to the JFO, JRO, or other teams and/or facilities to support disaster recovery operations. 
Liaison support may include, but is not limited to, the following: 
- USDA support to the JFO and/or AFO - USDA Local, State, Tribal, Territorial, and Federal Government Advisor(s).
 - Nonspecific Recovery Support Function (RSF) Field Coordinator (under NDRF).
- USDA Recovery Support SME(s).
- Contract or OFA audit support to ensure costs incurred under USDA Mission Assignments (MAs) meet all Stafford Act and regulatory requirements.
- Support to USDA Agencies and Programs.
- Providing Subject Matter Expertise to the Federal Coordinating Officer (FCO) and FCO Special Advisor for Recovery. 
- Providing technical assistance and collaboration with other agencies on recovery strategies/solutions, mitigation, resilience, and sustainability opportunities.
 - Developing and completing NDRF products that may include the Recovery Needs Assessment and/or performance tracking tools, as directed by the FCO and/or Special Advisor for Recovery.
 - Provide support either deployed onsite, episodically, or virtually as needed. 
- Develop an approach to support recovery, unique to the local communities and/or regional situation, working with and through existing USDA structures.
Additional information:
--- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), 
and duration of assignment(s).
--- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required 
for reimbursement.
--- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary 
to ensure reimbursement.
--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, 
services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective 
agency
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin 
#157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO 
Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

assistanceRequested:
Amendment #1: De-obligate $192,000 and reissue as 4754DR-ME-DOI-USGS-01.
USGS Field measurements of flood-water heights in impacted communities. Initial request for support at up to 600 locations.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) will provide advance support, real-time field measurements, and daily reporting of water heights in direct support and for situational awareness of FEMA disaster operations for a high-water or flood event.

USGS services may include, but are not limited to, the following in direct support of response and recovery operations:
 - Field measurements of flood water heights in impacted communities;
 - Deploy supplemental water-level measuring instruments.
 - Measure streamflow and discharge of flooded channels, directly or indirectly.
 - Flagging of High-Water Marks and collect evidence of flooding for impacted areas and communities. 
 - Locate and record the horizontal position and vertical elevation of the High Water Marks (HWM). 
 - Documentation of HWMs with field notes, digital photographs, and depth measurements to the ground at the HWM location at the time of inspection. 
 - Data measurements provided in GIS-ready format via the USGS National Water Information System or Short-Term Network system for display and download. 

ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
--- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
--- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
--- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

-Support to USDA Agencies and Programs
-Provide Subject Matter Expertise to the Federal Coordinating Officer (FCO) and Federal Disaster Recovery Officer (FDRO).
-Provide technical assistance and collaborate with other agencies on recovery strategies/solutions, mitigation, resilience, and sustainability opportunities.
-Develop and complete NDRF products that may include the Recovery Needs Assessment and/or performance tracking tools, as directed by the FDRO or FCO.
-Provide support either deployed onsite, episodically, or virtually as needed.
-Develop an approach to support recovery, unique to the local communities and/or regional situation, working with and through existing USDA structures.


ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency
- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations

Requesting use of appropriate space in the Fort Campbell AAFES. 
FEMA will use the premises primarily as a Disaster Recovery Center office where FEMA will receive survivors for the purpose of providing information such as the status of applications, and general information on FEMA disaster assistance.
statementOfWork:
Request appropriate space in the Fort Campbell AAFES for use as Disaster Recovery Center office. Provide life safety and lifesaving requirements as required by FEMA.
- Be prepared to provide EPLO LNO to serve as liaison between the base and FEMA.
MA task orders may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with a FEMA Project Manager. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. (refer Federal Personal Property Management Manual)
Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.

The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.
MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

Activate USACE in support of DR-4751-TN, severe weather and tornadoes in Tennessee at the IOF, JFO or other locations as needed.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will provide appropriate personnel to the IOF, JFO, or other facilities in support of disaster operations.  
Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
   - USACE support to National and/or Regional IMAT 
   - USACE modeling and/or National Hurricane Program support
  -  USACE Local Government Liaison(s)
   - USACE support to ESF #15 External Affairs
   - USACE SME(s)
  -  Infrastructure Systems Recovery Support Function (IS-RSF) Field Coordinator (under NDRF)
  - Contract or OFA audit support to ensure costs incurred under USACE MAs meet all Stafford Act and regulatory requirements
This mission assignment may also fund other site-specific personnel and non-mission specific administrative and management support at a Recovery Field Office (RFO) or other USACE node locations.  Those costs are not considered in this initial estimate.  Costs would vary based on the magnitude and duration of the response and recovery operations as authorized by FEMA.

statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will provide appropriate personnel to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities in support of disaster operations.  
Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
   - USACE support to RRCC 
   - USACE support to National and/or Regional IMAT 
   - USACE modeling and/or National Hurricane Program support
  -  USACE Local Government Liaison(s)
   - USACE support to ESF #15 External Affairs
   - USACE SME(s)
  -  Infrastructure Systems Recovery Support Function (IS-RSF) Field Coordinator (under NDRF)
  - Contract or OFA audit support to ensure costs incurred under USACE MAs meet all Stafford Act and regulatory requirements
This mission assignment may also fund other site-specific personnel and non-mission specific administrative and management support at a Recovery Field Office (RFO) or other USACE node locations. assistanceRequested:
Amend 01-De-Obligate (-100,000.00) per OFA partial closeout memo.  (Attached)
Activation of Temp Power Teams and/or Representatives to the Region 2 RRCC, IOF/JFO in New Jersey, New York, Puerto Rico and US Virgin Islands, and/or other facilities in support of FEMA disaster operations as defined in accordance with Region 2 Operations Order 2023-020 or as directed.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will pre-position temporary power support assets for emergency power generation to the affected area in support of disaster operations. 
Initial requirement is for, up to but not limited to, Type 4 temporary power support assets
Assets provided by FEMA will be returned to the Distribution Center (DC)/Remote Storage Site (RSS) stock Fully Mission Capable (FMC).  FEMA will supply or coordinate the acquisition of generators and associated Bill of Materials (BOM) (e.g. wires, connectors and load banks).  
Work includes providing personnel and equipment at the Federal/State staging area.  When directed by FEMA, USACE will conduct generator pre-installation operations.  USACE is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission including but not limited to Subject Matter Experts, members of the Planning and Response Team (PRT), 249th Engineer Battalion, DTOS and ACI contractor.
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
--- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
--- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
--- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.

--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

assistanceRequested:
Activation of GSA support for 4753DR-RI. 
Initial request is for GSA assistance with sourcing and leasing a commercial office space in Warwick RI.  Facility requirements 8,000 - 12,000sq. Ft. commercial office space. 
Additional requirements: ADA compliant, 75 - 100 parking spots, loading dock, wrap around services to be included.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, General Services Administration (GSA) will provide personnel to assist in leasing realty and/or contracting support and/or purchases as required to support FEMA disaster operations. Initial request is for GSA to find and assist in the leasing of a suitable location in Warwick, RI area. Details will be provided in a Mission Assignment Task Order as necessary.
--Funding of leases, contracts, or purchases in not authorized under this Mission Assignment. Leases, contracts, or purchases will be funded separately.
--MA task orders (MATOS) may be issues by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignments(s).

supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.

incidentName: R09 Guam Tropical Cyclone WPAC INVEST 98
assistanceRequested:
Amendment1:  De-obligate $20,000.00 and closeout Surge MA. 
This MA is being replaced with 3602EM-MP-DOD-OPS-03-00.

(DOD) will provide and support Saipan Army Reserve Center to function as an FSA/ISB in support of FEMA disaster operations.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Dept of Defense (DOD) will provide and support Saipan Army Reserve Center to function as a FEMA Incident Support Base (ISB), a Federal Staging Area (FSA) to support forward distribution of supplies or equipment, and/or a FEMA Federal Team Staging Facility (FTSF) for personnel and teams to as required in support of FEMA disaster operations. Initial installation requirements may include, but are not limited to: marshaling area for transportation trucks and trailers, storage space for generators and equipment, staging area for federal responders, and/or the personnel, equipment and Material Handling Equipment (MHE) to support operations.

incidentName: R09 Guam Tropical Cyclone WPAC INVEST 98
assistanceRequested: (DOD) will provide and support Saipan Army Reserve Center to function as an FSA/ISB in support of FEMA disaster operations.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Dept of Defense (DOD) will provide and support Saipan Army Reserve Center to function as a FEMA Incident Support Base (ISB), a Federal Staging Area (FSA) to support forward distribution of supplies or equipment, and/or a FEMA Federal Team Staging Facility (FTSF) for personnel and teams to as required in support of FEMA disaster operations. Initial installation requirements may include, but are not limited to: marshaling area for transportation trucks and trailers, storage space for generators and equipment, staging area for federal responders, and/or the personnel, equipment and Material Handling Equipment (MHE) to support operations.

incidentName: R09 Guam Tropical Cyclone WPAC INVEST 98
assistanceRequested:

USACE pre-position temporary emergency power resources to the affected area.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will pre-position temporary power support assets for emergency power generation to the affected area in support of disaster operations.
Initial requirement is for type IV temporary power support assets
Assets provided by FEMA will be returned to the Distribution Center (DC)/Remote Storage Site (RSS) stock Fully Mission Capable (FMC). FEMA will supply or coordinate the acquisition of generators and associated Bill of Materials (BOM) (e.g. wires, connectors and load banks).
Work includes providing personnel and equipment at the Federal/State staging area. When directed by FEMA, USACE will conduct generator pre-installation operations. USACE is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission including but not limited to Subject Matter Experts, members of the Planning and Response Team (PRT), 249th Engineer Battalion, DTOS and ACI contractor.
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
--- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
--- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
--- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

Activate ESF 3 USACE to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will provide appropriate personnel to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities in support of disaster operations.
Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- USACE support to RRCC
- USACE support to National and/or Regional IMAT
- USACE modeling and/or National Hurricane Program support
- USACE Local Government Liaison(s)
- USACE support to ESF #15 External Affairs
- USACE SME(s)
- Infrastructure Systems Recovery Support Function (IS-RSF) Field Coordinator (under NDRF)
- Contract or OFA audit support to ensure costs incurred under USACE MAs meet all Stafford Act and regulatory requirements
This mission assignment may also fund other site-specific personnel and non-mission specific administrative and management support at a Recovery Field Office (RFO) or other USACE node locations. Those costs are not considered in this initial estimate. Costs would vary based on the magnitude and duration of the response and recovery operations as authorized by FEMA.
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).

- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency
- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

incidentName: R09 Guam Tropical Cyclone WPAC INVEST 98

Amendment#1 De-obligate -$1,600,000.00 and close out MA. This MA is replaced by 3602EM-MP-HHS-ASPR-02-00
HHS to deploy DMAT teams in support of disaster operations.
statementOfWork: As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Health &  Human Services (HHS) will deploy National Disaster Medical System (NDMS) Disaster Medical Assistance Team (DMAT), National Veterinary Response Team (NVRT), Disaster Mortuary Operational Response Team (DMORT) medical response teams, personnel, and equipment to augment State and local medical response resources. NDMS team capabilities may include the following: - Primary and acute care, mass casualties triage, initial resuscitation and stabilization, advanced life support, and preparing the sick or injured for evacuation - Veterinary medical services in support of ESF #11 for service and companion animals - Mortuary assistance to recover, identify, and process deceased victims - Mass casualty decontamination; medical triage following a nuclear, biological, and/or chemical incidents. - Burn Teams - Pediatric Teams - Crush Medicine Teams - International Medical/Surgical Teams - Mental Health Teams Teams are composed of non-Federal volunteers who are placed on intermittent Federal appointments to facilitate activation, when necessary. When activated, NDMS response team members are Federalized employees of the HHS. Teams are normally deployed for 10 to 14 days. FEMA logistical support needed: Teams may require some level of base operating support (food, shelter, laundry, etc.). ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA: --- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). --- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. --- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. --- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA. --- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency --- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

Amendment #1 De-obligate -$80,436.00 and closeout MA. 

Activate DOE to RRCC. IOF, JFO, or other team(s) & facilities as requested.
statementOfWork: As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Dept of Energy (DOE) will provide appropriate personnel to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, SEOC, or other team(s) or facilities as requested to perform the functions of ESF-12 in support of disaster operations Funding for DOE command center(s), if authorized by FEMA, will be provided under a separate MA. - MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). - Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. - All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. - Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA. - The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency - MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

DOD strategic air transportation of personnel (non-medical patients) and/or cargo.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Dept of Defense (DOD) will provide transportation of personnel (nonmedical patients) and/or cargo, in support of FEMA disaster operations. DOD is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission, including Material Handling Equipment (MHE).

-All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.

-The mission assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective  agency.
-MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. 
-For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

incidentName: R09 Guam Tropical Cyclone WPAC INVEST 98
assistanceRequested:
Amendment #1 De-obligate $150,000.00 and closeout MA.
This MA is replaced by 3602EM-MP-DOD-OPS-02-00 (EM3602 CNMI) Dept of Defense (DOD) will provide interisland transportation (to include rotary wing transportation, fixed wing transportation, and sealift capabilities) of personnel, cargo, or commodities in support of FEMA disaster operations
statementOfWork:
As requested by and in coordination with FEMA and other appropriate civilian authorities, Dept of Defense (DOD) will provide interisland transportation (to include rotary wing transportation, fixed wing transportation, and sealift capabilities) of personnel, cargo, or commodities in support of FEMA disaster operations throughout Guam and CNMI. This support may include providing personnel, equipment, fuel, and all logistical support necessary to accomplish the mission.
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA: - MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). - Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. - All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. - Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA. - The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency - MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

incidentName: R09 Guam Tropical Cyclone WPAC INVEST 98
assistanceRequested:
Amendment #1 De-obligate-$20,000.00 and close out MA.

Provide Andersen AFB as a FEMA Incident Support Base (ISB), Federal Staging Area (FSA), and/or FEMA Federal Team Staging Facility in support of response and recovery operations.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Dept of Defense (DOD) will provide and support Anderson Air Force Base (AAFB) to function as a FEMA Incident Support Base (ISB), a Federal Staging Area (FSA) to support forward distribution of supplies or equipment, and/or a FEMA Federal Team Staging Facility (FTSF) for personnel and teams to as required in support of FEMA disaster operations. Initial installation requirements may include, but are not limited to: marshaling area for transportation trucks and trailers, storage space for generators and equipment, staging area for federal responders, and/or the personnel, equipment and Material Handling Equipment (MHE) to support operations.
- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). - Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. - All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. - Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA. - The mission assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency. - MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
