incidentName: R09 Guam Tropical Cyclone WPAC INVEST 98
assistanceRequested:
Amendment #1 De-obligate -$50,000.00 and close out MA.
This MA is replaced by 	3602EM-MP-DOD-OPS-01-00
Request DCO / DCE (including as necessary SEPLO/EPLO) assistance at the EOC, Joint Field Office, RRCC, or other locations specified by FEMA in support of disaster operations.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, DoD will activate and provide a Defense Coordinating Officer with supporting staff element (DCO/DCE Pacific) to the Guam/CNMI emergency management agencies, FEMA Initial Operating Facility, Joint Field Office, or other locations designated in Guam or CNMI, in order to provide DoD regional knowledge, mission requirement validation, and liaison capabilities. The DoD should also provide State/Emergency Preparedness Liaison SEPLO/EPLO teams, Joint Regional Medical Planning Officers (JRMPO), Command and Control (C2) elements, and logistics self-support as necessary to support the lead federal agency.ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
--- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
--- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
--- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

incidentName: R09 Guam Tropical Cyclone WPAC INVEST 98
assistanceRequested:
Amendment # 1 De obligate $2,000,000.00 and close out MA.
This MA is replaced by 3601EM-GU-COE-POD-02-00
USACE pre-position temporary emergency power resources to the affected area
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will pre-position temporary power support assets for emergency power generation to the affected area in support of disaster operations.
Initial requirement is for type IV temporary power support assets
Assets provided by FEMA will be returned to the Distribution Center (DC)/Remote Storage Site (RSS) stock Fully Mission Capable (FMC). FEMA will supply or coordinate the acquisition of generators and associated Bill of Materials (BOM) (e.g. wires, connectors and load banks).
Work includes providing personnel and equipment at the Federal/State staging area. When directed by FEMA, USACE will conduct generator pre-installation operations. USACE is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission including but not limited to Subject Matter Experts, members of the Planning and Response Team (PRT), 249th Engineer Battalion, DTOS and ACI contractor.
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
--- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
--- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
--- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

assistanceRequested:

This MA is replaced by 3601EM-GU-COE-POD-01-00
Activate ESF 3 USACE to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will provide appropriate personnel to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities in support of disaster operations.  
Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
   - USACE support to RRCC 
   - USACE support to National and/or Regional IMAT 
   - USACE modeling and/or National Hurricane Program support
  -  USACE Local Government Liaison(s)
   - USACE support to ESF #15 External Affairs
   - USACE SME(s)
  -  Infrastructure Systems Recovery Support Function (IS-RSF) Field Coordinator (under NDRF)
  - Contract or OFA audit support to ensure costs incurred under USACE MAs meet all Stafford Act and regulatory requirements
This mission assignment may also fund other site-specific personnel and non-mission specific administrative and management support at a Recovery Field Office (RFO) or other USACE node locations.  Those costs are not considered in this initial estimate.  Costs would vary based on the magnitude and duration of the response and recovery operations as authorized by FEMA.  
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
 - MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
 - Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
 - All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
 - Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
 - The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency

incidentName: R09 Guam Tropical Cyclone WPAC INVEST 98
assistanceRequested: Activate ESF 3 USACE to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will provide appropriate personnel to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities in support of disaster operations.  
Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
   - USACE support to RRCC 
   - USACE support to National and/or Regional IMAT 
   - USACE modeling and/or National Hurricane Program support
  -  USACE Local Government Liaison(s)
   - USACE support to ESF #15 External Affairs
   - USACE SME(s)
  -  Infrastructure Systems Recovery Support Function (IS-RSF) Field Coordinator (under NDRF)
  - Contract or OFA audit support to ensure costs incurred under USACE MAs meet all Stafford Act and regulatory requirements
This mission assignment may also fund other site-specific personnel and non-mission specific administrative and management support at a Recovery Field Office (RFO) or other USACE node locations.  Those costs are not considered in this initial estimate.  Costs would vary based on the magnitude and duration of the response and recovery operations as authorized by FEMA.  
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
 - MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
 - Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
 - All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
 - Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
 - The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
 - MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

incidentName: R09 Guam Tropical Cyclone WPAC INVEST 98
assistanceRequested: HHS to deploy DMAT teams in support of disaster operations.
statementOfWork: As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Health & Human Services (HHS) will deploy National Disaster Medical System (NDMS) Disaster Medical Assistance Team (DMAT), National Veterinary Response Team (NVRT), Disaster Mortuary Operational Response Team (DMORT) medical response teams, personnel, and equipment to augment State and local medical response resources. NDMS team capabilities may include the following: - Primary and acute care, mass casualties triage, initial resuscitation and stabilization, advanced life support, and preparing the sick or injured for evacuation - Veterinary medical services in support of ESF #11 for service and companion animals - Mortuary assistance to recover, identify, and process deceased victims - Mass casualty decontamination; medical triage following a nuclear, biological, and/or chemical incidents. - Burn Teams - Pediatric Teams - Crush Medicine Teams - International Medical/Surgical Teams - Mental Health Teams Teams are composed of non-Federal volunteers who are placed on intermittent Federal appointments to facilitate activation, when necessary. When activated, NDMS response team members are Federalized employees of the HHS. Teams are normally deployed for 10 to 14 days. FEMA logistical support needed: Teams may require some level of base operating support (food, shelter, laundry, etc.). ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA: --- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). --- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. --- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. --- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA. --- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency --- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

incidentName: R09 Guam Tropical Cyclone WPAC INVEST 98
assistanceRequested: Radio Frequency (RF) Spectrum Management and Coordination.  FCC spectrum management coordination in support of disaster operations
statementOfWork:
As requested by and in coordination with FEMA, Federal Communications Commission (FCC) will provide spectrum management 
assistance in support of FEMA disaster operations. Specific capabilities provided and activities performed may 
include but are not limited to the following: -Management of radio frequencies. -Assistance with submission of frequency 
assignment requests. -  Resolution of frequency interference issues. -Facilitating requests for Radio Frequency 
spectrum. - Advising Federal leadership on spectrum issues.  -Coordinating frequencies for incoming Federal first 
responder communications assets and systems, including: assisting with State, local, Tribal, industry, and volunteer 
organization interoperability issues; providing technical guidance and coordination of Special Temporary Assignments 
and assignment modification routing for Federal responders; facilitating connectivity to FCC, Washington, D.
C - MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration 
of assignment(s). - Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation 
is required for reimbursement. - All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project 
Manager. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. - Activation of agency command center(s), 
if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA. - The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring 
that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable 
and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency - MAs shall be considered for closure after 
180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests 
for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been 
provided.

Funding for DOT command center(s), if authorized by FEMA, will be provided under a separate MA.
- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency
- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

(DOD) will provide and support Saipan Army Reserve Center to function as an FSA/ISB in support of FEMA disaster operations. This MA replaces MP23100501DOD-OPS0100
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Dept of Defense (DOD) will provide and support Saipan Army Reserve Center to function as a FEMA Incident Support Base (ISB), a Federal Staging Area (FSA) to support forward distribution of supplies or equipment, and/or a FEMA Federal Team Staging Facility (FTSF) for personnel and teams to as required in support of FEMA disaster operations. Initial installation requirements may include, but are not limited to: marshaling area for transportation trucks and trailers, storage space for generators and equipment, staging area for federal responders, and/or the personnel, equipment and Material Handling Equipment (MHE) to support operations.
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA: --- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). --- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. --- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. --- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA. --- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency --- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided. .

incidentName: R09 Guam Tropical Cyclone WPAC INVEST 98
assistanceRequested:
Amendment #3 De-obligate -$3,624.48 per July 2024 QULO Report. 

Amendment #2: De-obligate -$71,375.52 per Jan 2024 Quarterly ULO Report. 
Amendment #1- Increase funds by $25,000.00 and extend POP to 10/17/2023.
Request DCO / DCE (including as necessary SEPLO/EPLO) assistance at the EOC, Joint Field Office, RRCC, or other locations specified by FEMA in support of disaster operations.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, DoD will activate and provide a Defense Coordinating Officer with supporting staff element (DCO/DCE Pacific) to the Guam/CNMI emergency management agencies, FEMA Initial Operating Facility, Joint Field Office, or other locations designated in Guam or CNMI, in order to provide DoD regional knowledge, mission requirement validation, and liaison capabilities. The DoD should also provide State/Emergency Preparedness Liaison SEPLO/EPLO teams, Joint Regional Medical Planning Officers (JRMPO), Command and Control (C2) elements, and logistics self-support as necessary to support the lead federal agency.ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
--- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
--- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
--- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

Deploy USCG liaison officer(s) to RRCC, IOF, JFO, STT EOC or other facility(s)
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) will provide appropriate personnel to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other locations to support disaster operations. This may include but is not limited to the following:
  - USCG Liaison Officers (RRCC, IOF, JFO, STT EOC)
  - USCG ESF Watch Officers (typically ESFs -1 (Maritime Transportation System (MTS)), -9 (SAR), and -10 (Oil/Hazmat))
  - Other USCG SMEs, as applicable

incidentName: R09 Guam Tropical Cyclone WPAC INVEST 98
assistanceRequested:
Amendment # 2 De-obligate $200,000.00 and await final invoices 
Amendment 1 De-oligate $500,000 per attached MEMO
USACE pre-position temporary emergency power resources to the affected area.  This MA replaces MP-23100501COE-POD-02-00.
This amended IFMIS is a transition from Pre-Declaration Surge to an Emergency Declaration to include additional funding in the amount of $1,394,050 making cumulative amount $3,394,050 to include the Start Date of the Verbal MA# COE-POD-02V, 6 Oct 2023 and pushing the Estimated Projected End Date to 20 Oct 2023.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will pre-position temporary power support assets for emergency power generation to the affected area in support of disaster operations.
Initial requirement is for type IV temporary power support assets
Assets provided by FEMA will be returned to the Distribution Center (DC)/Remote Storage Site (RSS) stock Fully Mission Capable (FMC). FEMA will supply or coordinate the acquisition of generators and associated Bill of Materials (BOM) (e.g. wires, connectors and load banks).
Work includes providing personnel and equipment at the Federal/State staging area. When directed by FEMA, USACE will conduct generator pre-installation operations. USACE is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission including but not limited to Subject Matter Experts, members of the Planning and Response Team (PRT), 249th Engineer Battalion, DTOS and ACI contractor.
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
--- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
--- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
--- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

USACE pre-position temporary emergency power resources to the affected area.  This MA replaces MP-23100501COE-POD-02-00.
This amended IFMIS is a transition from Pre-Declaration Surge to an Emergency Declaration to include additional funding in the amount of $1,394,050 making cumulative amount $3,394,050 to include the Start Date of the Verbal MA# COE-POD-02V, 6 Oct 2023 and pushing the Estimated Projected End Date to 20 Oct 2023.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will pre-position temporary power support assets for emergency power generation to the affected area in support of disaster operations.
Initial requirement is for type IV temporary power support assets
Assets provided by FEMA will be returned to the Distribution Center (DC)/Remote Storage Site (RSS) stock Fully Mission Capable (FMC). FEMA will supply or coordinate the acquisition of generators and associated Bill of Materials (BOM) (e.g. wires, connectors and load banks).
Work includes providing personnel and equipment at the Federal/State staging area. When directed by FEMA, USACE will conduct generator pre-installation operations. USACE is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission including but not limited to Subject Matter Experts, members of the Planning and Response Team (PRT), 249th Engineer Battalion, DTOS and ACI contractor.
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
--- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
--- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
--- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

incidentName: R09 Guam Tropical Cyclone WPAC INVEST 98
assistanceRequested:
Amendment #3: De-obligate -$21,660.86 and closeout MA per April 2024 Quarterly ULO Report. 
Amendment #2 to extend POP to 10/20/2023. No cost extension
Admin Error: This amended IFMIS is a transition from Pre-Declaration Surge to an Emergency Declaration to include the Start Date of the MA MP-23100501-COE-POD- 01-00 6 Oct 2023 through Projected End Date to 17 Oct 2023.
Activate ESF 3 USACE to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities. 
This MA replaces MP-23100501-COE-POD- 01.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will provide appropriate personnel to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities in support of disaster operations.  
Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
   - USACE support to RRCC 
   - USACE support to National and/or Regional IMAT 
   - USACE modeling and/or National Hurricane Program support
  -  USACE Local Government Liaison(s)
   - USACE support to ESF #15 External Affairs
   - USACE SME(s)
  -  Infrastructure Systems Recovery Support Function (IS-RSF) Field Coordinator (under NDRF)
  - Contract or OFA audit support to ensure costs incurred under USACE MAs meet all Stafford Act and regulatory requirements
This mission assignment may also fund other site-specific personnel and non-mission specific administrative and management support at a Recovery Field Office (RFO) or other USACE node locations.  Those costs are not considered in this initial estimate.  Costs would vary based on the magnitude and duration of the response and recovery operations as authorized by FEMA.  
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
 - MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
 - Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
 - All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
 - Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
 - The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
 - MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) will provide appropriate personnel to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other locations to support disaster operations. This may include but is not limited to the following:
  - USCG Liaison Officers (RRCC, IOF, JFO, STT EOC)
  - USCG ESF Watch Officers (typically ESFs -1 (Maritime Transportation System (MTS)), -9 (SAR), and -10 (Oil/Hazmat))
  - Other USCG SMEs, as applicable

Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:

 - National Risk Management Center (Geospatial and Infrastructure analyst SME)

statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will pre-position temporary power support assets for emergency power generation to the affected area in support of disaster operations.
Initial requirement is for type IV temporary power support assets
Assets provided by FEMA will be returned to the Distribution Center (DC)/Remote Storage Site (RSS) stock Fully Mission Capable (FMC). FEMA will supply or coordinate the acquisition of generators and associated Bill of Materials (BOM) (e.g. wires, connectors and load banks).
Work includes providing personnel and equipment at the Federal/State staging area. When directed by FEMA, USACE will conduct generator pre-installation operations. USACE is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission including but not limited to Subject Matter Experts, members of the Planning and Response Team (PRT), 249th Engineer Battalion, DTOS and ACI contractor.
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
--- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
--- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
--- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

incidentName: R09 Guam Tropical Cyclone WPAC INVEST 98
assistanceRequested:
Amendment#1: De-obligate -$29,328.66 per April 2024 Quarterly ULO Report. 

Activate ESF 3 USACE to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities. 
This amended IFMIS is a transition from Pre-Declaration  Surge to an Emergency Declaration to include  initial funding in the amount of 100,000 and to include the Start Date of the MA# GU23100501COE-POD-01-00, 6 Oct 2023 through  Projected End Date to 14 Oct 2023.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will provide appropriate personnel to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities in support of disaster operations.  
Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
   - USACE support to RRCC 
   - USACE support to National and/or Regional IMAT 
   - USACE modeling and/or National Hurricane Program support
  -  USACE Local Government Liaison(s)
   - USACE support to ESF #15 External Affairs
   - USACE SME(s)
  -  Infrastructure Systems Recovery Support Function (IS-RSF) Field Coordinator (under NDRF)
  - Contract or OFA audit support to ensure costs incurred under USACE MAs meet all Stafford Act and regulatory requirements
This mission assignment may also fund other site-specific personnel and non-mission specific administrative and management support at a Recovery Field Office (RFO) or other USACE node locations.  Those costs are not considered in this initial estimate.  Costs would vary based on the magnitude and duration of the response and recovery operations as authorized by FEMA.  
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
 - MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
 - Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
 - All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
 - Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
 - The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
 - MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

Activate USACE Infrastructure RSF Field Coordinator
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will provide appropriate personnel to the NRCC, RRCC, IOF, JFO, JRO or other facilities in support of National Disaster Recovery Framework post-disaster operations.

Support personnel may include, but is not limited to the following:
- USACE support to the JFO and/or JRO
- Infrastructure Systems Recovery Support Function (IS-RSF) Field Coordinator (under the NDRF)
- IS-RSF Recovery Support SME(s)

The Infrastructure Systems RSF Field Coordinator support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
 Provide Subject Matter Expertise to the Federal Coordinating Officer (FCO) and Federal Disaster Recovery Officer (FDRO).
 Convene federal partnering agencies supporting the IS-RSF, formalize communications/meetings with the IS-RSF, and serve as the federal point-person for all IS-RSF-related matters at the field level. Maintain regular internal coordination/communication related to RSF initiatives at the field, regional, and national levels and ensure work in the disaster-affected area is consistent with the Recovery Strategy Development.
 Develop an approach to support infrastructure systems recovery, unique to the local communities and/or regional situation.
 Provide technical assistance and collaborate with other agencies on recovery strategies/solutions, mitigation, resilience, and sustainability opportunities. Assist RSF agencies in continuing to incorporate a comprehensive, multi-sector approach on coordination activities that align with the Recovery Strategy Development.
 Develop and complete NDRF products that may include the Recovery Needs Assessment and/or performance tracking tools, as directed by the FDRO or FCO.
 In consultation with the National RSF Coordinator, serve as an agency representative or agency liaison.
 Monitor supported and implemented recovery programs.
 Provide support either deployed onsite, episodically, or virtually as needed.

The IS-RSF Field Coordinator may be selected based upon several key criteria beyond that of subject matter experience. The selected individual ideally will:
 Be either housed in, or intimately aware of the affected region.
 Have experience coordinating infrastructure issues as well as experience or knowledge of mitigation and resilience. Reach back capability for technical support of these areas is suitable.
 Have experience managing staff, planning and meeting facilitation.

IS-RSF activation may also include applicable USACE agency program area Subject Matter Experts (SMEs). Those SME costs are not considered in this initial estimate. Costs would vary based on the magnitude and duration of the disaster recovery operations as authorized by FEMA.


---MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
--- Agencies will be re imbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
--- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, General Services Administration (GSA) will provide personnel to assist in leasing realty and/or contraction support and/or purchasing as required to support FEMA disaster operations.  

--Funding of leases, contracts, or purchases in not authorized under this Mission Assignment. Leases, contracts, or purchases will be funded separately.

--The mission assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are receive, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and
supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.
--MAs shall be considered for closure after 45 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MA's still operationally open, requests for additional
obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

statementOfWork:
Security of FEMA facilities will be based on FEMA Office of Chief Security Officer (OCSO) security standards, policies, and practices. statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Air Force Auxiliary/Civil Air Patrol (CAP) will provide aircraft, vehicles, and/or personnel in support of FEMA disaster operations.

Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
Aerial/ground imaging (video, still photography, imagery, 2D/3Ddata)
Transportation of personnel and/or light cargo
Damage assessment imagery/observations, which may include previously collected imagery
Geotagged or georeferenced imagery, uploadable to FEMAprovided FTP website or delivered on digital media
CAP liaison and/or imagery collection management support
Airborne communications relay (repeater) missions in support of FEMA Urban Search & Rescue/LifeSafety

ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
The mission assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency
MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA,  DHS Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) will provide appropriate personnel to the RRCC, JFO, IOF, or other teams and facilities in support of disaster operations.

Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
 - ESF-14 coordination and delivery of products and services
 - ESF-5 regarding critical physical and cyber infrastructure
- Analysis of impacts to Lifelines and National Critical Infrastructure 

CISA liaisons may include representatives from  
 - Integrated Operations Division (ESF14)
 - Infrastructure Security Division (Infrastructure SME) 
 - National Risk Management Center (Geospatial SME)

Activation of ESF 03 Representatives to the Region 2 RRCC, IOF/JFO in New Jersey, New York, Puerto Rico and US Virgin Islands, and/or other facilities in support of FEMA disaster operations as defined in accordance with Region 2 Operations Order  2023-015 or as directed.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will provide appropriate personnel to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities in support of disaster operations.  

Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
   - USACE support to RRCC 
   - USACE support to National and/or Regional IMAT 
   - USACE modeling and/or National Hurricane Program support
  -  USACE Local Government Liaison(s)
   - USACE support to ESF #15 External Affairs
   - USACE SME(s)
  -  Infrastructure Systems Recovery Support Function (IS-RSF) Field Coordinator (under NDRF)
  - Contract or OFA audit support to ensure costs incurred under USACE MAs meet all Stafford Act and regulatory requirements

This mission assignment may also fund other site-specific personnel and non-mission specific administrative and management support at a Recovery Field Office (RFO) or other USACE node locations.  Those costs are not considered in this initial estimate.  Costs would vary based on the magnitude and duration of the response and recovery operations as authorized by FEMA.

 - MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
 - Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
 - All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
 - Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
 - The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
 - MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

assistanceRequested:
Amend 3 - De-obligate ($500,000 FY 23) per USACE partial closeout memo
Amend 2 - De-obligate ($100,000 FY 23) per USACE partial closeout memo
Amend 1 - De-obligate ($150,000 FY 23) as per attached request from USACE POC
Activation of Temp Power Teams and/or Representatives to the Region 2 RRCC, IOF/JFO in New Jersey, New York, Puerto Rico and US Virgin Islands, and/or other facilities in support of FEMA disaster operations as defined in accordance with Region 2 Operations Order 2023-015 or as directed.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will pre-position temporary power support assets for emergency power generation to the affected area in support of disaster operations. 

Initial requirement is for, up to but not limited to, Type 4 temporary power support assets

Assets provided by FEMA will be returned to the Distribution Center (DC)/Remote Storage Site (RSS) stock Fully Mission Capable (FMC).  FEMA will supply or coordinate the acquisition of generators and associated Bill of Materials (BOM) (e.g. wires, connectors and load banks).  

Work includes providing personnel and equipment at the Federal/State staging area.  When directed by FEMA, USACE will conduct generator pre-installation operations.  USACE is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission including but not limited to Subject Matter Experts, members of the Planning and Response Team (PRT), 249th Engineer Battalion, DTOS and ACI contractor.

ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
--- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
--- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
--- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

Request United States Air Auxiliary/Civil Air Patrol provide CAP LNO support at the FEMA NRCC in response to HC Lee.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Air Force Auxiliary/Civil Air Patrol (CAP) will provide aircraft, vehicles, and/or personnel in support of FEMA disaster operations.
Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- Aerial/ground imaging (video, still photography, imagery, 2D/3Ddata)
- Transportation of personnel and/or light cargo
- Damage assessment imagery/observations, which may include previously collected
imagery
- Geo-tagged or georeferenced imagery, up-loadable to FEMA-provided FTP website or
delivered on digital media
- CAP liaison and/or imagery collection management support
- Airborne communications relay (repeater) missions in support of FEMA Urban Search & Rescue/Life-Safety
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
--- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
--- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
--- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. 
- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA. 
- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

Activate USACE to the NRCC or other facilities to support disaster operations
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will provide appropriate personnel to the NRCC, or other facilities in support of disaster operations.
Activation may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- USACE support to NRCC
- USACE support to National IMAT
- USACE support to ESF #15 External Affairs
- USACE SME(s)
- Infrastructure Systems Recovery Support Function (IS-RSF) Field Coordinator (under NDRF)
- USACE modeling and/or National Hurricane Program support
- Contract or OFA audit support to ensure costs incurred under USACE MA meet all Stafford Act and regulatory requirements.

--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

IMT: 15 person x 7 days
Two 16 person Federal Agent/Law Enforcement Strike Teams (LEST NIMS Typing Terminology.  Formerly QRT IAW US&R Memo FEMA HQ) x 7 days

statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Dept of Justice (DOJ)/ATF will provide appropriate personnel to staff ESF#13 Incident Management Team(s) (IMT), Management Support Team(s) (MST) to direct ESF#13 Field Force Protection/Security Operations in support FEMA disaster operations.
Additionally, the Department of Justice/ATF will provide Federal Law enforcement officer (FLEO) Law Enforcement Strike Teams (LEST) or other security teams as required to provide force protection in support of disaster operations.

supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
-MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional
obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

USGS Field measurements of flood-water heights in impacted communities
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) will provide advance support, real-time field measurements, and daily reporting of water heights in direct support and for situational awareness of FEMA disaster operations for a high-water or flood event.

USGS services may include, but are not limited to, the following in direct support of response and recovery operations:
 - Field measurements of flood water heights in impacted communities;
 - Deploy supplemental water-level measuring instruments.
 - Measure streamflow and discharge of flooded channels, directly or indirectly.
 - Flagging of High-Water Marks and collect evidence of flooding for impacted areas and communities. 
 - Locate and record the horizontal position and vertical elevation of the High Water Marks (HWM). 
 - Documentation of HWMs with field notes, digital photographs, and depth measurements to the ground at the HWM location at the time of inspection. 
 - Data measurements provided in GIS-ready format via the USGS National Water Information System or Short-Term Network system for display and download. 

ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
--- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
--- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
--- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

USAF Auxiliary, Civil Air Patrol (CAP) Northeast Region (NER) aerial support.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Air Force Auxiliary/Civil Air Patrol (CAP) will provide aircraft, vehicles, and/or personnel in support of FEMA disaster operations.
Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- Aerial/ground imaging (video, still photography, imagery, 2D/3Ddata).
- Transportation of personnel and/or light cargo.
- Damage assessment imagery/observations, which may include previously collected imagery.
- Geo-tagged or georeferenced imagery, up-loadable to FEMA-provided FTP website or delivered on digital media.
- CAP liaison and/or imagery collection management support.
- Airborne communications relay (repeater) missions in support of FEMA Urban Search & Rescue/Life-Safety.
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
--- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
--- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
--- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Requesting DOD provide Westover ARB Incident Support Base (ISB) in support of Tropical Cyclone Lee Response.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Dept. of Defense (DOD) will provide and support a facility to function as a FEMA Incident Support Base (ISB) as required in support of FEMA disaster response operations.
Initial installation requirements may include, but are not limited to, the following:
- Staging for up to 75 tractor trailer trucks to pre;stage commodities.
- Permit FEMA to provide equipment and supplies for FEMA use. This property and other removable property will remain FEMA property in the exclusive control and authority of
FEMA and will be removed by FEMA upon termination of the FOS mission assignment.
- DOD is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission including but not limited to: 24 hour security and escort services for incoming tractor trailers, wrap around services to include dumpster, port-o-johns, hand washing station, and light towers if necessary.
Additional notes from FEMA:   
- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).

assistanceRequested: Requesting DOD provide Westover ARB Incident Support Base (ISB) in support of Tropical Cyclone Lee Response.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Dept. of Defense (DOD) will provide and support a facility to function as a FEMA Incident Support Base (ISB) as required in support of FEMA disaster response operations.
Initial installation requirements may include, but are not limited to, the following:
- Staging for up to 75 tractor trailer trucks to pre;stage commodities.
- Permit FEMA to provide equipment and supplies for FEMA use. This property and other removable property will remain FEMA property in the exclusive control and authority of
FEMA and will be removed by FEMA upon termination of the FOS mission assignment.
- DOD is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission including but not limited to: 24 hour security and escort services for incoming tractor trailers, wrap around services to include dumpster, port-o-johns, hand washing station, and light towers if necessary.
Additional notes from FEMA:   
- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).

-  The mission-;assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and
supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency
-  MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional
obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

assistanceRequested:
-Amendment #1: De-obligate and reissue as 3598EM-ME-NOAA-02.

NOAA aircraft, survey crew, and remote sensing equipment to provide information regarding the nature and extent of an incident and cascading effects
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, National Oceanic & Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) will provide support which may include, but is not limited to, rapidly collecting, processing, and distributing high resolution, geo-rectified aerial imagery and/or Light Detection and Ranging (LIDAR) data in support of disaster operations.
NOAA personnel will participate in Interagency Remote Sensing Coordination Cell (IRSCC) planning meetings, provide technical and operational planning expertise to facilitate aerial survey planning, and coordinate survey operations with other agencies (via the IRSCC, if activated).
NOAA is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission.
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
 - MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).

 - MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

Activate ESF-3, USACE to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will provide appropriate personnel to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities in support of disaster operations.  
Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
   - USACE support to RRCC 
   - USACE support to National and/or Regional IMAT 
   - USACE modeling and/or National Hurricane Program support
  -  USACE Local Government Liaison(s)
   - USACE support to ESF #15 External Affairs
   - USACE SME(s)
  -  Infrastructure Systems Recovery Support Function (IS-RSF) Field Coordinator (under NDRF)
  - Contract or OFA audit support to ensure costs incurred under USACE MAs meet all Stafford Act and regulatory requirements
This mission assignment may also fund other site-specific personnel and non-mission specific administrative and management support at a Recovery Field Office (RFO) or other USACE node locations.  Those costs are not considered in this initial estimate.  Costs would vary based on the magnitude and duration of the response and recovery operations as authorized by FEMA.  
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
 - MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
 - Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
 - All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
 - Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
 - The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
 - MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

assistanceRequested:
-Amendment #1: De-obligate and reissue as 3598EM-ME-COE-LRD-01.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
USACE pre-position temporary emergency power resources to the affected area(s)
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will pre-position temporary power support assets for emergency power generation to the affected area in support of disaster operations. 

Initial requirement is for two type IV temporary power support assets.

Assets provided by FEMA will be returned to the Distribution Center (DC)/Remote Storage Site (RSS) stock Fully Mission Capable (FMC).  FEMA will supply or coordinate the acquisition of generators and associated Bill of Materials (BOM) (e.g. wires, connectors and load banks).  

Work includes providing personnel and equipment at the Federal/State staging area.  When directed by FEMA, USACE will conduct generator pre-installation operations.  USACE is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission including but not limited to Subject Matter Experts, members of the Planning and Response Team (PRT), 249th Engineer Battalion, DTOS and ACI contractor.

ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
--- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
--- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
--- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will pre-position temporary power support assets for emergency power generation to the affected area in support of disaster operations. 

Initial requirement is for two type IV temporary power support assets.

Assets provided by FEMA will be returned to the Distribution Center (DC)/Remote Storage Site (RSS) stock Fully Mission Capable (FMC).  FEMA will supply or coordinate the acquisition of generators and associated Bill of Materials (BOM) (e.g. wires, connectors and load banks).  

Work includes providing personnel and equipment at the Federal/State staging area.  When directed by FEMA, USACE will conduct generator pre-installation operations.  USACE is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission including but not limited to Subject Matter Experts, members of the Planning and Response Team (PRT), 249th Engineer Battalion, DTOS and ACI contractor.

ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
--- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
--- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
--- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

This is a reissue of MA-23090401-USGS-01:  USGS Field measurements of flood-water heights in impacted communities
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) will provide advance support, real-time field measurements, and daily reporting of water heights in direct support and for situational awareness of FEMA disaster operations for a high-water or flood event.
USGS services may include, but are not limited to, the following in direct support of response and recovery operations:
 - Field measurements of flood water heights in impacted communities;
 - Deploy supplemental water-level measuring instruments.
 - Measure streamflow and discharge of flooded channels, directly or indirectly.
 - Flagging of High-Water Marks and collect evidence of flooding for impacted areas and communities. 
 - Locate and record the horizontal position and vertical elevation of the High Water Marks (HWM). 
 - Documentation of HWMs with field notes, digital photographs, and depth measurements to the ground at the HWM location at the time of inspection. 
 - Data measurements provided in GIS-ready format via the USGS National Water Information System or Short-Term Network system for display and download. 
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
--- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
--- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
--- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

Title-32
DOD provide up to 50 personnel to assist state to execute emergency protective measures to mitigate the impacts of COVID-19. This replaces MA#1509-327341-4521DR-NE-DOD-02, subject to a (25% state cost share). Mission will be incrementally funded with initial cost estimated at $960,000.00 for operations beginning 8/22/20 through 9/30/20. Additional funding requirements will be provided by NGB J8 thereafter. Original state signed RRF is being used to support the MA due to clarification in the SOW for billing purposes.
statementOfWork:
Consistent with President Trumps Memorandum Providing Federal Support for Governors Use of the National Guard to Respond to COVID-19, dated 3 August 2020, to assist the State of Nebraska to respond to the threats and hazards caused by COVID-19, FEMA requests DoD provide essential assistance support to the State of Nebraska.  Pursuant to President Trumps Memoranda, FEMA can fully reimburse DoD for this support if DoD requests that States order National Guard Forces to perform duty to fulfill this mission assignment.  DOD will execute the MA as directed by and in coordination with FEMA, and will: Provide essential assistance to meet the immediate threats to life resulting from the COVID-19 outbreak as authorized by Sections 403 (42 U.S.C. 5170b) of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act, Public Law 93-288, as amended, 42 U.S.C. 5121 et seq., to support COVID-19 operations in Nebraska.  National Guard units under state control will execute critical missions to save lives and protect the public health and safety. Eligible activities are limited to Emergency Protective Measures, as outlined in COVID-19 specific Public Assistance policy or otherwise authorized by FEMA.  Safety and security missions, not to include law enforcement activities, are authorized as part of this MA.  Effective 8/22/2020, eligible costs under this MA include pay, allowances, travel to place National Guard personnel on Title 32 orders, and per diem. Eligible expenses will also include: 1. Operating costs for DoD equipment already in DoD stocks necessary to fulfill the MA; and 2. Equipment and supplies that only DoD can purchase and that are necessary to fulfill the requirements of the MA, and pre-approved by the FEMA project Manager, 3. Lastly, additional eligible expenses authorized in writing by ORR leadership Employment costs (supplies, equipment, etc.) will be the responsibility of the state, and ineligible MA expenses may be submitted for reimbursement consideration to FEMA via a Public Assistance Project Worksheet. FEMA can offer 100% reimbursement to DOD for this support, if it is executed with National Guard personnel under Title 32 pursuant to the Presidents August 3 proclamation on Providing Federal Support for Governors Use of the National Guard to Respond to COVID-19.
DOD will deploy with appropriate command and control, support personnel, and equipment as required.  In support of this activity, the State will develop a transition plan for this support that will reflect the current mission sets, the conditions required to either terminate or transition the missions, the means of transition (i.e., contracted, other state agency, or National Guard in state active-duty), and the projected timeline to transition.  States will submit the initial plan to FEMA not later than 45 days after this mission assignment is executed and will provide an update on the status of transition no later than 60 days prior to final date T-32 authorized via Presidential Memoranda. All local, State, and non-DoD national assets are exhausted or do not have the capacity to meet this requirement. - Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA. - The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency. - MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

This is a reissue of MA-23090401-DOD-USAF-01:  USAF Civil Air Patrol (CAP) to provide imagery support to Region 1.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Air Force Auxiliary/Civil Air Patrol (CAP) will provide aircraft, vehicles, and/or personnel in support of FEMA disaster operations.

Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- Aerial/ground imaging (video, still photography, imagery, 2D/3Ddata)
- Transportation of personnel and/or light cargo
- Damage assessment imagery/observations, which may include previously collected
imagery
- Geo-tagged or georeferenced imagery, up-loadable to FEMA-provided FTP website or
delivered on digital media
- CAP liaison and/or imagery collection management support
- Airborne communications relay (repeater) missions in support of FEMA Urban Search & Rescue/Life-Safety

ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
--- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
--- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
--- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

This is a reissue of MA-23090401-DOD-OPS-02:  Requesting DOD provide Westover ARB Incident Support Base (ISB) in support of Tropical Cyclone Lee Response.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Dept. of Defense (DOD) will provide and support a facility to function as a FEMA Incident Support Base (ISB) as required in support of FEMA disaster response operations.
Initial installation requirements may include, but are not limited to, the following:
- Staging for up to 75 tractor trailer trucks to pre-stage commodities.
- Permit FEMA to provide equipment and supplies for FEMA use. This property and other removable property will remain FEMA property in the exclusive control and authority of
FEMA and will be removed by FEMA upon termination of the FOS mission assignment.
- DOD is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission including but not limited to 24-hour security and escort services for incoming tractor trailers, wrap around services to include dumpster, port-o-johns, hand washing station, and light towers if necessary.
Additional notes from FEMA:   
- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
- The mission assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and
supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.
- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional
obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided

assistanceRequested: This is a reissue of MA-23090401-DOC-NOAA-02:  NOAA aircraft, survey crew, and remote sensing equipment to provide information regarding the nature and extent of an incident and cascading effects
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, National Oceanic & Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) will provide support which may include, but is not limited to, rapidly collecting, processing, and distributing high resolution, geo-rectified aerial imagery and/or Light Detection and Ranging (LIDAR) data in support of disaster operations.

NOAA personnel will participate in Interagency Remote Sensing Coordination Cell (IRSCC) planning meetings, provide technical and operational planning expertise to facilitate aerial survey planning, and coordinate survey operations with other agencies (via the IRSCC, if activated).

NOAA is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission.

ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
 - MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
 - Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
 - All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.

statementOfWork:
