This is a reissue of MA-23090401-COE-NAD-01:  Activate ESF-3, USACE to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will provide appropriate personnel to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities in support of disaster operations.  

Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
   - USACE support to RRCC 
   - USACE support to National and/or Regional IMAT 
   - USACE modeling and/or National Hurricane Program support
  -  USACE Local Government Liaison(s)
   - USACE support to ESF #15 External Affairs
   - USACE SME(s)
  -  Infrastructure Systems Recovery Support Function (IS-RSF) Field Coordinator (under NDRF)
  - Contract or OFA audit support to ensure costs incurred under USACE MAs meet all Stafford Act and regulatory requirements

This mission assignment may also fund other site-specific personnel and non-mission specific administrative and management support at a Recovery Field Office (RFO) or other USACE node locations.  Those costs are not considered in this initial estimate.  Costs would vary based on the magnitude and duration of the response and recovery operations as authorized by FEMA.  

ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
 - MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
 - Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
 - All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
 - Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
 - The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
 - MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

This is a reissuance of MA-23090401-COE-LRD-01:  Pre-position temporary emergency power resources to Region 1.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will pre-position temporary power support assets for emergency power generation to the affected area in support of disaster operations. 
Initial requirement is for two type IV temporary power support assets.
Assets provided by FEMA will be returned to the Distribution Center (DC)/Remote Storage Site (RSS) stock Fully Mission Capable (FMC).  FEMA will supply or coordinate the acquisition of generators and associated Bill of Materials (BOM) (e.g. wires, connectors and load banks).  
Work includes providing personnel and equipment at the Federal/State staging area.  When directed by FEMA, USACE will conduct generator pre-installation operations.  USACE is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission including but not limited to Subject Matter Experts, members of the Planning and Response Team (PRT), 249th Engineer Battalion, DTOS and ACI contractor.

Activate USACE to the NRCC or other facilities to support disaster operations. This MA replaces ME-23090401-COE-HQ-01 with no change in funding or POP.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will provide appropriate personnel to the NRCC, or other facilities in support of disaster operations.

Activation may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- USACE support to NRCC
- USACE support to National IMAT
- USACE support to ESF #15 External Affairs
- USACE SME(s)
- Infrastructure Systems Recovery Support Function (IS-RSF) Field Coordinator (under NDRF)
- USACE modeling and/or National Hurricane Program support
- Contract or OFA audit support to ensure costs incurred under USACE MA meet all Stafford Act and regulatory requirements.

USAF Auxiliary, Civil Air Patrol (CAP) aerial support for SC
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Air Force Auxiliary/Civil Air Patrol (CAP) will provide aircraft, vehicles, and/or personnel in support of FEMA disaster operations.

Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- Aerial/ground imaging (video, still photography, imagery, 2D/3Ddata)
- Transportation of personnel and/or light cargo
- Damage assessment imagery/observations, which may include previously collected
imagery
- Geo-tagged or georeferenced imagery, up-loadable to FEMA-provided FTP website or
delivered on digital media
- CAP liaison and/or imagery collection management support
- Airborne communications relay (repeater) missions in support of FEMA Urban Search & Rescue/Life-Safety

NOAA aircraft, survey crew, and remote sensing equipment to provide information regarding the nature and extent of an incident and cascading effects from Hurricane Idalia in the state of South Carolina.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, National Oceanic & Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) will provide support which may include, but is not limited to, rapidly collecting, processing, and distributing high resolution, geo-rectified aerial imagery and/or Light Detection and Ranging (LIDAR) data in support of disaster operations.
NOAA personnel will participate in Interagency Remote Sensing Coordination Cell (IRSCC) planning meetings, provide technical and operational planning expertise to facilitate aerial survey planning, and coordinate survey operations with other agencies (via the IRSCC, if activated).
NOAA is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission.

DoD provide personnel and equipment to assist state to execute protective measures to mitigate disaster operations for COVID-19 in State of Nebraska. This is for reimbursement of Title 32 Forces.
Initial requests for emergency protective measures capability from the DoD should be for no more than 1000 personnel with command and control, support personnel and equipment to begin on April 14, 2020 and end on May 28, 2020 unless otherwise specified in writing.  Requests that exceed this threshold will incur additional time for sourcing and additional cost.  Additional capability may be requested via MATO or amendment to this MA as appropriate. Cost Estimate: $17,063,640 (Personnel & Projected O&M Costs). Requested Resource Activation DoD. 14 April -28 May, 2020.
statementOfWork:
NOTE: SOW DOES NOT FIT IN FULL, SEE ATTACHMENT
Consistent with President Trumps Memorandum Providing Federal Support for Governors Use of the National Guard to Respond to COVID-19, dated April 14, 2020 to assist the State of Nebraska to respond to the threats and hazards caused by COVID-19, FEMA requests DoD provide essential assistance support to the State of Nebraska Pursuant to Section 3 of President Trumps Memorandum, FEMA can fully reimburse DoD for this support, to include pay and allowances, if DoD requests that States order National Guard Forces to perform duty to fulfill this mission assignment. The Department of Defense (DOD) will execute these mission assignments as directed by and in coordination with FEMA, and will: 
Provide essential assistance to meet the immediate threats to life resulting from the COVID-19 outbreak as authorized by Sections 403 (42 U.S.C. 5170b) of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act, Public Law 93-288, as amended, 42 U.S.C. 5121 et seq., to support COVID-19 operations in Nebraska. National Guard units under state control will execute critical missions to save lives and protect the public health and safety. 
Safety and security missions, not to include law enforcement activities, are authorized as part of this mission assignment. Purchase of commodities, with the exception of commodities required for sustainment, is not authorized as part of this mission assignment. These missions, if necessary, should be handled through separate mission assignments. 
FEMA can offer 100% reimbursement for this support, including pay and allowances, if it is executed with National Guard personnel under Title 32 pursuant to Section 3 of the Presidents April 14, 2020 proclamation on Providing Federal Support for Governors Use of the National Guard to Respond to COVID-19. 
DoD will deploy with appropriate command and control, support personnel, and equipment as required. Contracting for sustainment and lodging to sustain the personnel is authorized, as required. 
All local, State, and non-DoD national assets are exhausted or do not have the capacity to meet this requirement. 
Initial Cost Estimate and Cost Breakout* 
Initial Cost: $17,050,000 
MA Cost Based on: $550/soldier/day x # soldiers x 31 days = Total Reimbursable Authority 
550 x1000 x 31=$17,050,000 
Emergency Protective Measures: 
As appropriate, Emergency Protective Measures to be performed by DoD personnel include but are not limited to: 
- Management, control and reduction of immediate threats to public health and safety; 
Manning of Emergency Operation Centers 
Planning to support State COVID-19 response operations 
Disinfection of eligible public facilities 
Technical assistance to state, tribal, territorial or local governments on emergency management and control of immediate threats to public health and safety.

assistanceRequested:
Amendment 1:  De-obligate $56,594.79 as indicated on the 01-01-20204 QULO response. Also changing PM to Daniel Carpenter. 
NOAA aircraft, survey crew, and remote sensing equipment to provide information regarding the nature and extent of an incident and cascading effects from Hurricane Idalia in the state of Georgia.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, National Oceanic & Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) will provide support which may include, but is not limited to, rapidly collecting, processing, and distributing high resolution, geo-rectified aerial imagery and/or Light Detection and Ranging (LIDAR) data in support of disaster operations.
NOAA personnel will participate in Interagency Remote Sensing Coordination Cell (IRSCC) planning meetings, provide technical and operational planning expertise to facilitate aerial survey planning, and coordinate survey operations with other agencies (via the IRSCC, if activated).
NOAA is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission.
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
 - MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
 - Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
 - All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
 - Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
 - The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
 - MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

assistanceRequested:
Amendment #3 to deobligate $4,469,451.00 and close. MA is replaced by MA 4734DR-FL-HHS-ASPR- 03
 Amendment #2 - Extend projected end date to 09/11/2023, missed in previous amendment
Amendment #1 - Add additional funding of $4,394,451.00
Activation for appropriate HHS personnel to perform the functions of ESF 8 in the RRCC, IOF, JFO, Incident Management Assistance Team (IMAT), Preliminary Damage Assessment (PDA) Team, or other teams and locations to support disaster operations.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Health and Human Services (HHS) will provide appropriate personnel to RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other teams, LNOs, SMEs, and facilities as requested.
MA task orders may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. 
All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with a FEMA Project Manager.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. (refer Federal Personal Property Management Manual). Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement, per 44 CFR 206.208(c)(2).   
The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency. 
MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. 
For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

Department of Justice/ATF will provide Federal Law enforcement officer (FLEO) Law Enforcement Strike Teams (LEST), LNOs to State EOC and RRCC, Incident/Management Teams and Mobile Command Vehicle/ (MCV)Mobile Bunk Houses (MBH) as required to provide force protection in support of disaster operations.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the Department of Justice/ATF will provide Federal Law enforcement officer (FLEO) Law Enforcement Strike Teams (LEST) Incident Management personnel, Management Support Team personnel, RRCC LNOs and State EOC LNOs as required to incident supervision, coordination and force protection in support of disaster operations.
- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency
- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Air Force Auxiliary/Civil Air Patrol (CAP) will provide personnel to the RRCC, IOF, JFO or other locations to support disaster operations.

Support may include but is not limited to the following:
- CAP Liaison Officers

ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
 MA task orders (MATOs) will be issued by FEMA's AOB at the RRCC or FL SEOC to provide specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
- The CAP LNO should report to the FL SEOC (2555 Shumard Oak Blvd, Tallahassee, FL 32399) with appropriate equipment to fully execute all required tasks.
 Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
 All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
 Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
 The missionassigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency
 MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

LNO deployment notification and locations should be requested with the National CAP Liaison as soon as practicable.

The MA/MATO should specify if 24-hour ops are needed and/or additional specialties/personnel are needed.

Ops longer than 7-days, may require on-station relief of personnel.

incidentName: R04 Tropical System in West Carib/Gulf
assistanceRequested:
Amendment #1 - deobligate $10,000.00 and closed. MA replaced by MA 4734DR-FL-DOD-OPS- 01
As requested by and in coordination with FEMA, DOD will provide a Defense Coordinating Officer/Element (DCO/E) supporting staff and services and back up Defense Coordinating Officer/Element (DCO/E) supporting staff and services as required/requested. Regional and State Emergency Preparedness Liaison Officers (REPLOS and SEPLOS) to the RRCC, IOF, or other locations to provide DOD regional knowledge, requirements validation, and liaison.
statementOfWork: As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, DOD will provide Defense Coordination Officer(s) with supporting staff element(s) (DCO/DCE) to the RRCC, Region IV Joint Field Office, IOF, or other locations, to provide DOD regional knowledge, requirements validation, and liaison, including as necessary State/Emergency Preparedness Liaison SEPLO/EPLO teams. Supporting staff element, augmentees, Joint Regional Medical Planning Officer (JRMPO), as mission required/requested. MA task orders may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. Prior Federal Approving Official (FAO) approval is necessary to ensure reimbursement. Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement, per 44 CFR 206.208(c)(2). Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agencies. MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157 and MA Policy 104-010-2. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

statementOfWork:
At the direction of, and in coordination with FEMA security personnel, FPS will provide appropriate physical security to
support response and recovery operations in the various venues in Region 4. Security of FEMA facilities will be based
on FEMA security standards, policies and practices. For FPS accounting purposes this MA and associated funds are intended
to fund FEMA task orders for the period specified or until funds are exhausted. Any time extensions or additional
funding requirements will be processed utilizing an RRF including new POP (period of performance) dates, cost
estimate and justification. This information will be provided by FEMA Security in coordination with FPS personnel and
approved by the FCO or his/her designee. Equipment purchases are not authorized under this mission assignment.
- MA task orders may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration
of assignment (s).
- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required
for reimbursement.

received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective
agency
- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA
CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing,
ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

assistanceRequested: CBP-AMO provide Marine, Rotary, and/or Fixed-Wing asset support
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP), Air and Marine Operations (AMO) will provide appropriate aircraft, marine vessels, personnel, or other assets to support disaster operations.

Requested support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- Logistics (passenger, commodity, and equipment transport)
- Aerial imaging (still or full-motion video) for situational awareness
- Reconnaissance

ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
--- Initial request is for two UH-60s, with one being hoist capable.
--- MA task orders (MATOs) will be issued by FEMA's AOBD at the RRCC or FL SEOC for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
--- A CPB LNO should report to the FL SEOC (2555 Shumard Oak Blvd, Tallahassee, FL 32399) with appropriate equipment (i.e., laptop) to fully execute all required tasks.
--- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
--- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

incidentName: R04 Tropical System in West Carib/Gulf
assistanceRequested:
Amendment #2  - deobligate $115,500.00 and close . Replaced with MA 4734DR-FL-COE-SAD-01
Amendment #1 - Add additional funding of $94,500.00 for additional SMEs
Activate USACE to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities
statementOfWork: As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will provide appropriate personnel to the RRCC, IOF, JFO, or other facilities in support of disaster operations. Support may include, but is not limited to, the following: - USACE support to RRCC - USACE support to National and/or Regional IMAT - USACE modeling and/or National Hurricane Program support - USACE Local Government Liaison(s) - USACE support to ESF #15 External Affairs - USACE SME(s) - Infrastructure Systems Recovery Support Function (IS-RSF) Field Coordinator (under NDRF) - Contract or OFA audit support to ensure costs incurred under USACE MAs meet all Stafford Act and regulatory requirements This mission assignment may also fund other site-specific personnel and non-mission specific administrative and management support at a Recovery Field Office (RFO) or other USACE node locations. Those costs are not considered in this initial estimate. Costs would vary based on the magnitude and duration of the response and recovery operations as authorized by FEMA. ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA: - MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). - Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. - All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. - Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA. - The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency - MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

incidentName: R04 Tropical System in West Carib/Gulf
assistanceRequested:
Amendment #2 -  De-obligate $7,021,405.00 and close.  MA replaced with 4734DR-FL-COE-LRD-01. 
Amendment #1 - Add additional funding of $5,221,405.00 to increase the Temp Power PRT to a TYPE II
USACE preposition Type IV temporary emergency power resources to Maxwell AFB ISB.
statementOfWork: As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will pre-position temporary power support assets for emergency power generation to the affected area in support of disaster operations. Initial requirement is for Type IV temporary power support assets, adjusted as needed. Assets provided by FEMA will be returned to the Distribution Center (DC)/Remote Storage Site (RSS) stock Fully Mission Capable (FMC). FEMA will supply or coordinate the acquisition of generators and associated Bill of Materials (BOM) (e.g. wires, connectors and load banks). Work includes providing personnel and equipment at the Federal/State staging area. When directed by FEMA, USACE will conduct generator pre-installation operations. USACE is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission including but not limited to Subject Matter Experts, members of the Planning and Response Team (PRT), 249th Engineer Battalion, DTOS and ACI contractor. ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA: --- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). --- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. --- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. --- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA. --- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency --- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

incidentName: R04 Tropical System in West Carib/Gulf
assistanceRequested: BOC 2501 (SCF) IRS to provide DHS/FEMA with additional staff to augment existing cadres.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA Internal Revenue Services will provide Surge Capacity Force personnel consisting of permanent agency staff willing to deploy for a field assignment to augment FEMAs disaster operations.
TREAS - IRS will provide employees who have been identified as Surge Capacity Force (SCF) members at specified tier (Tier 3 or Tier 4) in accordance with standards in the DHS Surge Capacity Force Program Interim Guide, dated August 2022.
NOTE: Agencies do not receive advances of funds from FEMA to pay for mission assigned activities. FEMA must receive and approve a request for payment for mission assignment work, accompanied by supporting documentation, to process reimbursement from the Disaster Relief Fund (DRF).

ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
--- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
--- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
--- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

- ESF-7 support
- Emergency leasing services for needed space/facilities as requested by FEMA
- GSA Lease Contracting Officers (LCOs) and others as needed

-Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
-The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency
-MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

incidentName: R04 Tropical System in West Carib/Gulf
assistanceRequested:
Amendment #2- De-obligate $34,429.66 and close MA per OFA request
Amendment #1 - Extend projected end date to 04/01/2024.
Provide USACE Reemployed Annuitant Cadre personnel to work on program projects for buildings and equipment, roads and bridges, electric cooperatives and others as needed. DR-4738-GA deploying personnel as HM 406 Specialists, or any other role as deemed necessary by field leadership.
statementOfWork:
As requested by and in coordination with FEMA, USACE and or Reemployed Annuitant Cadre (RAC) will deploy personnel to the State of Georgia in support of Hurricane Idalia Recovery Efforts. USACE Reemployed Annuitant (RA) personnel will serve as either Public Assistance Mitigation Site Inspectors (STSP), Public Assistance Mitigation Engineer or any other position as deemed necessary by the Hazard Mitigation Branch Director and/or the Hazards and Performance Analysis Group Supervisor.
Tasks to be Performed, but not limited to:
1. Applying policy and procedure to Applicant briefings, recovery scoping meetings, site inspections and follow up meetings.
2. Inspect and evaluate damaged facilities to determine areas for potential mitigation during repair, reconstruction with adherence to engineering best practices and the model ordinances and codes.
3. Provide technical assistance to Public Assistance staff (PA) in identifying and developing hazard mitigation proposals.
4. Provide technical assistance to PA staff by reviewing PA Projects for sound mitigation opportunities/techniques.
5. Provide technical assistance on compliance with codes, specifications, standards and regulations.
6. Provide technical support to stakeholders on Benefit Cost Analysis (BCA) utilizing the FEMA approved BCA tool.
USACE is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission, and/or may issue a subtasking
to another Federal agency for that support.
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
The mission assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency
MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

(RSF) As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) will provide appropriate personnel to the JFO, JRO, or other teams and/or facilities to support disaster operations.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Department of Agriculture (USDA) provides appropriate personnel in support of FEMA disaster operations. Initial activation of the USDA to provide federal coordination with the appropriate Recovery Support Function (RSF) primary and support agencies, other Federal Agencies, and SLTT partners as directed by FEMA. USDA to provide specific expertise to create and deliver a Recovery Needs Assessment (RNA) and subsequent recovery strategies in conjunction with RSFs to deliver support to affected communities. USDA will provide recovery needs assessments and strategy coordination by using the spectrum of technical expertise and programs offered: loans, grants and loan guarantees to help create jobs and support economic development and essential services such as housing; health care; first responder services and equipment; water, electric and communications infrastructure; promote economic development by supporting loans to businesses through banks, credit unions and community managed lending pools; offer technical assistance and information to help agricultural producers and cooperatives recover and improve the effectiveness of their operations; and help rural residents buy or rent safe, affordable housing and make health and safety repairs to their homes. USDA will also provide specific expertise and support the Federal Coordinating Officer (FCO) and Federal Disaster Recovery Officer (FDRO) or their deputies throughout the development and completion of the RNA and recovery products. The RNA will include recovery strategies that support SLTT partners goals and objectives for a holistic and resilience recovery. The USDA Advisor/Field Coordinator designated, in consultation with the National Coordinator, may request additional support via Subject Matter Experts from pertinent Primary and Supporting agencies to support, on an operation by operation basis. USDA will participate in Interagency Recovery Coordination meetings and strategic work session required to complete the different RSF areas of the Recovery Needs Assessment, contributing USDA Rural programs specific data and information so the RNA is an interdependent assessment that fully addresses impacts of disaster, and provides recovery outcomes that are real solutions. The USDA Advisors will contribute through collaboration to integrated plans that address rural communities sector related solutions, and mitigation opportunities as well as opportunities for resilience and sustainability.
Costs would vary based on the requirements and duration of the disaster recovery operations as authorized by FEMA.
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
MA task orders may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with a FEMA Project Manager. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. (refer Federal Personal Property Management Manual) Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
The mission assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency MA shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

Activate the United States Small Business Administration (SBA) to provide appropriate Recovery Support Function (RSF) personnel in support of the National Disaster Recovery Framework (NDRF) and FEMA post-disaster recovery operations for DR-4734-FL Hurricane Idalia.
statementOfWork:
As directed by, and in coordination with FEMA, SBA will provide support to the Economic RSF (ERSF) Field Coordinator through onsite and virtual support to the FEMA led Interagency Recovery Coordination efforts and through engagement with community stakeholders. The SBA Field Coordinator will provide federal coordination and connections to the RSF coordinating, 
primary, and supporting agencies, other Federal Agencies, state, local, and tribal partners, and the private sector as directed by FEMA. The support will be for Hurricane Idalia (Florida) in the federally declared areas.
Recovery products may include, but are not limited to:
�	A Recovery Needs Assessment
�	Development of Recovery Strategy (format TBD)
�	Stakeholder and state and local partner engagements and/or trainings which may include small meetings as well as larger Economic Recovery Workshops, as determined to be valuable by stakeholders and SBA.
MA task orders may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).  
Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.  
All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with a FEMA Project Manager. If approved, 
documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement (refer to Federal Personal Property Management Manual).
Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement, per 44 CFR 206.208(c)(2).
The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency.
MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157.
For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided

NGA Geospatial Intelligence (GEOINT) support to the FEMA Urban Search and Rescue (US&R) Red Incident Support Team.
This MA replaces MA 3596EM-FL-NGA-01
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency (NGA) will deploy Geospatial Analyst Team(s) to assist the Urban Search & Rescue (US&R) Incident Support Team and deployed task forces in support of the TC Idalia response.
Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- MGST Trailer
- NGA analysts to provide analytical expertise
- NGA operational support staff including contractors to support operations, satellite communications, and sheltering and feeding of NGA staff (a total of 3 personnel to provide mobile GEOINT)
NGA is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission.
 - MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
 - Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
 - All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
 - Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
 - The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
 - MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

State of Florida requests DMATs with billeting package and DMAT cache to support and augment Florida's Medical System. To provide health and medical care within the healthcare infrastructure for individuals impacted by Hurricane Idalia. Initial request is for 2
statementOfWork:
In support of Florida Department of Health as directed by FEMA, HHS will provide and execute lifesaving and life-sustaining Federal ESF-8 public health and medical assets, personnel, and associated equipment caches in support of the 2023 Idalia response. Assets to be supported by HHS Incident Management Team (IMT), engaging personnel and necessary equipment caches.
MA task orders may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with a FEMA Project Manager. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. (refer Federal Personal Property Management Manual)
Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement, per 44 CFR 206.208(c)(2).
The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency
MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

(SCF) Requesting External Affairs support for DR 4734 FL
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, General Services Administration will provide Surge Capacity Force personnel consisting of permanent agency staff willing to deploy for a field assignment to augment FEMAs disaster operations. GSA will provide employees who have been identified as Surge Capacity Force (SCF) members at specified tier (Tier 3 or Tier 4) in accordance with standards in the DHS Surge Capacity Force Program Interim Guide, dated August 2022. 
 Agencies do not receive advances of funds from FEMA to pay for mission assigned activities. FEMA must receive and approve a request for payment for mission assignment work, accompanied by supporting documentation, to process reimbursement from the Disaster Relief Fund (DRF). 
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency. 
 MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

incidentName: R04 Tropical System in West Carib/Gulf
assistanceRequested:
Amendment #1 - Correct end date mis-entered previously, correct end date shoud be 09/29/2023.
State of Florida requests Landfill Strike Teams to support and augment debris disposal and management operations in response to hurricane Idalia. This MA replaces 3596EM-FL-EPA-04.
statementOfWork: In support of Florida request, as directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) will conduct oil and hazardous materials field operations, including assessment, mitigation, cleanup and disposal of hazardous materials and oil and response to orphaned containers and/or fixed facilities in support of FEMA disaster operations. These necessary emergency protective measures will mitigate actual and potential threats to public health and safety. In close coordination with FEMA, EPA response operations may also include the following: household hazardous waste identification, collection, and disposal evaluating and monitoring immediate public health and safety threats or hazards resulting from debris removal operations The assistance may include response to eliminate or lessen immediate threats to lives, public health, or safety emanating from actual or potential releases and/or discharges; Support of field personnel by EPA personnel deployed virtually; providing specialized expertise related to oil/hazmat impacts or release; conducting damage assessment of oil/hazmat impact via air, soil, and/or water; contractor oversight; and/or response, removal, mitigation, staging or disposal oversight of actual and potential oil discharges and releases of hazardous materials. EPA will coordinate activities involving contaminated debris with USACE as appropriate. Actions may include support by any special teams requested by the Federal on Scene Coordinator (FOSC) and in coordination with FEMA, as well as special technical assets of all ESF #10 support agencies. EPA is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission. MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.  Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.  The mission assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency   MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

 - MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
 - Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
 - All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
 - Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
 - The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
 - MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

USAF Auxiliary, Civil Air Patrol (CAP) aerial support for FL.  This replaces FL-23082403-DOD-USAF-01.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Air Force Auxiliary/Civil Air Patrol (CAP) will provide aircraft, vehicles, and/or personnel in support of FEMA disaster operations.
Support may include, but is not limited to, the following:
- Aerial/ground imaging (video, still photography, imagery, 2D/3Ddata)
- Transportation of personnel and/or light cargo
- Damage assessment imagery/observations, which may include previously collected
imagery
- Geo-tagged or georeferenced imagery, up-loadable to FEMA-provided FTP website or
delivered on digital media
- Fully mission ready CAP liaison and/or imagery collection management support*
- Airborne communications relay (repeater) missions in support of FEMA Urban Search & Rescue/Life-Safety
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
--- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).

--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

CAP LNO to FL AOB for aerial imagery following landfall of Idalia across Florida for damage assessment determination.  This is a re-issue of FL-23082403-DOD-USAF-03.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Air Force Auxiliary/Civil Air Patrol (CAP) will provide personnel to the RRCC, IOF, JFO or other locations to support disaster operations.
Support may include but is not limited to the following:
- CAP Liaison Officers
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
 MA task orders (MATOs) will be issued by FEMA's AOB at the RRCC or FL SEOC to provide specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
- The CAP LNO should report to the FL SEOC (2555 Shumard Oak Blvd, Tallahassee, FL 32399) with appropriate equipment to fully execute all required tasks.
 Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
 All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
 Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
 The missionassigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency
 MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
LNO deployment notification and locations should be requested with the National CAP Liaison as soon as practicable.
The MA/MATO should specify if 24-hour ops are needed and/or additional specialties/personnel are needed.
Ops longer than 7-days, may require on-station relief of personnel.

agency

Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

As requested by and in coordination with FEMA, DOD will provide a Defense Coordinating Officer/Element (DCO/E) supporting staff and services and back up Defense Coordinating Officer/Element (DCO/E) supporting staff and services as required/requested. Regional and State Emergency Preparedness Liaison Officers (REPLOS and SEPLOS) to the RRCC, IOF, or other locations to provide DOD regional knowledge, requirements validation, and liaison.
Replaces previous MA FL-23082403-DOD-OPS-02 and add additional funding of $10,000.00
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, DOD will provide Defense Coordination Officer(s) with supporting staff element(s) (DCO/DCE) to the RRCC, Region IV Joint Field Office, IOF, or other locations, to provide DOD regional knowledge, requirements validation, and liaison, including as necessary State/Emergency Preparedness Liaison SEPLO/EPLO teams. Supporting staff element, augmentees, Joint Regional Medical Planning Officer (JRMPO), as mission required/requested.
MA task orders may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. Prior Federal Approving Official (FAO) approval is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
Work that falls within the statutory authority of the performing Federal agency is not eligible for FEMA reimbursement, per 44 CFR 206.208(c)(2). Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agencies.
MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157 and MA Policy 104-010-2. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

incidentName: R04 Tropical System in West Carib/Gulf
assistanceRequested: Activate NOAA to NRCC to support FEMA disaster operations.  This MA replaces 3596EM-FL-DOC-NOAA-0100
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) will provide appropriate personnel to the NRCC to support disaster operations
This may include but is not limited to, the following:
    - National Weather Service (NWS) Meteorologist(s) and/or Hydrologist(s)
    - National Weather Service (NWS) Hurricane Liaison Team (HLT)
    - National Ocean Service (NOS) Personnel with coastal resource and management expertise
    - Support to ESF-5 to provide meteorological onsite expertise, coordination, and analysis
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
  - MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
 - Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
 - All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
 - Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
 - The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
 - MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

NOAA Identification of Pollution Targets This MA replaces 3596EM-FL-DOC-NOAA- 03.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Dept of Commerce/National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) will identify potential pollution target(s) in support of disaster  operations. 
   
Support may include, but is not limited to, determining location of oil & hazmat release(s) or debris posing threats to life safety, the environment, and/or maritime transportation systems.

assistanceRequested:
Amendment 1: De-obligate $52,058.24 per Quarterly ULO Validation Report. Change PM to Kevin Stewart.
NOAA aircraft, survey crew, and remote sensing equipment to provide information regarding the nature and extent of an incident and cascading effects in the state of Florida from Hurricane Idalia. This MA replaces 3596EMFL-DOC-NOAA-02
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, National Oceanic & Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) will provide support which may include, but is not limited to, rapidly collecting, processing, and distributing high resolution, geo-rectified aerial imagery and/or Light Detection and Ranging (LIDAR) data in support of disaster operations.
NOAA personnel will participate in Interagency Remote Sensing Coordination Cell (IRSCC) planning meetings, provide technical and operational planning expertise to facilitate aerial survey planning, and coordinate survey operations with other agencies (via the IRSCC, if activated).
NOAA is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission.
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
 - MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
 - Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
 - All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager.  If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
 - Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.   
 - The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
 - MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

assistanceRequested:
Amendment 1. De-obligate $48,065.93 per agency request. Change PM to Scott Schaefer.
DOC/NIST surface level observations acquired using ARA resources. The observations are Wind Speed. These data are provided shortly after landfall and help narrow down the areas with greatest impacts. Impacts guide field support (i.e., USAR and DSA) and help with the damage assessment process. The data are delivered electronically via email.  This MA replaces 3596EMFL-DOC-NIST-01
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Dept of Commerce/National Institute of Standards and Technology (DOC/NIST) will provide situation awareness in support of disaster operations. 
Support may include, but is not limited to, utilization of ARA resources to acquire the following:
  - wind speed (gust and mean)
  - wind direction
  - atmospheric pressure
Areas to be covered include, but are not limited to, are regions impacted by Hurricane Idalia in Florida.

assistanceRequested:

Amendment 1. Extend POP to 05/03/2024. Add $211,227.80 in additional funding. Change PM to Angela Barton.
(RSF) Activate Department of Commerce (DOC) Economic development Administration (EDA) to provide appropriate Recovery Support Function (RSF) personnel in support of the National Disaster Recovery Framework (NDRF) and FEMA post disaster recovery operations for DR4734FL.
Hurricane Idalia
statementOfWork:
As directed by, and in coordination with FEMA, EDA will serve as an Economic RSF (ERSF) Field Coordinator through virtual and in person support to the FEMA led Interagency Recovery Coordination efforts. The ESRF Field Coordinator will provide federal coordination and connections to the appropriate RSF primary and support agencies, other Federal Agencies, and STTL partners as directed by FEMA. The support will be for the Florida State Hurricane in the federally declared areas. Deliverables will likely include: A Recovery Needs Assessment A Recovery Options Strategy Document (format TBD) Stakeholder engagement which may include small meetings as well as larger Economic Recovery Workshops, as determined to be valuable by stakeholders and ERSF. 
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA Project Manager. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA. The mission assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

assistanceRequested:
(SCF)Amendment 1:  As per SCF project manager, personnel are no longer needed they are mission complete as of 9/30
(SCF) DHS-MGMT to provide DHS/FEMA with additional staff to augment existing cadres.
statementOfWork:
As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Department of Homeland will provide Surge Capacity Force personnel consisting of permanent agency staff willing to deploy for a field assignment to augment FEMA's disaster operations.
DHS-MGMT will provide employees who have been identified as Surge Capacity Force (SCF) members at specified tier (Tier 3 or Tier 4) in accordance with standards in the DHS Surge Capacity Force Program Interim Guide, dated August 2022.
NOTE: Agencies do not receive advances of funds from FEMA to pay for mission assigned activities. FEMA must receive and approve a request for payment for mission assignment work, accompanied by supporting documentation, to process reimbursement from the Disaster Relief Fund (DRF).
ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
--- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
--- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
--- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
--- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
--- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency
--- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

incidentName: R04 Tropical System in West Carib/Gulf
assistanceRequested:
Amendment # 1 De-obligate $4,377,353.00 and close per USCG POC
State of Florida requests USCG inland SAR to perform rescue operations.
This MA replaces 3596EM-FL-DHS-USCG-03
statementOfWork:
In support of Florida request, as directed by and in coordination with FEMA, U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) will provide Catastrophic Incident
 Search and Rescue (CISAR) capability for catastrophic incidents, as defined by the CISAR Addendum and/or CG Addendum to the United States National Search and Rescue Supplement (NSS), to support STT disaster operations. USCG will provide resources appropriate to conduct lifesaving Search and Rescue missions for sustained, large-scale rescue operations. Resources will be tasked by MATO.
 USCG is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment necessary to accomplish the mission.
 ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA:
 --- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s).
 --- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement.
 --- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement.
 --- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
 --- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and
 that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency
 --- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still
 operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been
 provided.
 -- Federal regulation prohibits FEMA from mission assigning other Federal agencies (OFA) for work falling within the OFAs independent authority.
 See 44 CFR 206.208(c)(2). Federal regulation also prohibits FEMA from reimbursing an OFA for carrying out work under its independent authority.
 See 44 CFR 206.8(b). Funding under this mission assignment and any resulting mission assignment task orders will be limited to work performed
 outside of the OFAs independent authority.

incidentName: R04 Tropical System in West Carib/Gulf
assistanceRequested: Provide security officers as required by the field security manager and regional security officer (RSO) at various venues in support of disaster operations.  This is a re-issue of FL-23082403-DHS-FPS-01.
statementOfWork:
At the direction of, and in coordination with FEMA security personnel, FPS will provide appropriate physical security to
support response and recovery operations in the various venues in Region 4. Security of FEMA facilities will be based
on FEMA security standards, policies and practices. For FPS accounting purposes this MA and associated funds are intended
to fund FEMA task orders for the period specified or until funds are exhausted. Any time extensions or additional
funding requirements will be processed utilizing an RRF including new POP (period of performance) dates, cost
estimate and justification. This information will be provided by FEMA Security in coordination with FPS personnel and
approved by the FCO or his/her designee. Equipment purchases are not authorized under this mission assignment.
- MA task orders may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration
of assignment (s).
- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required
for reimbursement.
- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA.
- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are
received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective
agency
- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA
CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing,
ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.
